title: The Intersection of Cars and High Fashion
promoTitle: The Intersection of Cars and High Fashion
promoTeaserSmall: You may not think that cars and designers go together, but the Jean Knows Cars team is here to tell you that they do.
promoTeaser: You may not think that cars and designers go together, but the Jean Knows Cars team is here to tell you that they do.
keywords: Intersection of Cars and High Fashion
metaTitle: The Intersection of Cars and High Fashion
metaDescription: The Intersection of Cars and High Fashion. Read about how cars and fashion go hand in hand on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Jean is still waiting for the perfect car-inspired millinery, and that desire has grown since she saw the cunning link between cars and fashion drawn by Prada’s 2012 spring/summer collection.

The Italian fashion house showed off purses emblazoned with cars, stiletto heels with flames borrowed from hot-rod graphics, and nursery-style car prints on blouses, skirts, and scarves. All of these have been copied widely.

pageElements.title: Prada's car-inspired fantasy footwear and accessories channeled the 1950s.

pageElements.text: The link between horsepower and high fashion is natural: designers are fond of saying that cars and clothing are two of the most revealing things about a person. Cars are considered to be basically another layer of clothing when you go out into the world, and that's all the more true in visually oriented and status-obsessed places like Los Angeles.

Automakers continue to be hip to this connection, frequently hooking up with fashion designers to put a special spin on their vehicles. Witness the Fiat 500 Gucci model, which sells for $24,200 and borrows the iconic Gucci stripe for the car’s exterior trim and seatbelt straps. Even expensive supercars like the Lamborghini Murciélago have received the haute couture treatment. Versace put its hand to the Murciélago in the past, adding such details as the fashion house’s signature Greek key motif on the lower doors and front fascia, as well as a hand embroidered motif on the black-and-white leather seats. And let us not forget Bugatti's $2-million-plus Bugatti Veyron Fbg by Hermès—featuring extensive use of bull calfskin inside and out—at the 2008 Geneva Auto Show.

pageElements.title: Fiat 500 by Gucci: The designer name added even more Italian chic to the little car.

pageElements.text: It’s not unusual for car designers to come out of the fashion industry either. Ford’s Anthony Prozzi, a senior interior designer, began his design career in fashion as a designer at Donna Karan.
“The thought that goes into designing a new vehicle is extensive,” Prozzi says. “And it’s very similar in many ways to the creative process fashion designers follow when they’re creating clothing.”
The road runs in both directions. Joe Ponce, a former designer at Ford and General Motors, switched his focus to footwear and now designs high-end shoes for Gwen Stefani’s L.A.M.B. label.

title: Automatic Stop/Start Technology
subTitle: Saving fuel in a car near you
promoTeaserSmall: Saving fuel and saving you money while leaving the fun where it belongs.
promoTeaser: Saving fuel and saving you money while leaving the fun where it belongs.
metaTitle: Automatic Stop/Start Technology - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Automatic Stop/Start Technology : Learn more about this fuel-saving technology, which is becoming more popular in mainstream cars, at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: With fuel economy standards steadily increasing (the latest regulations will require fleets to average 54.5 mpg by 2025), automakers are introducing fuel-saving gadgets wherever they can. One technology, already widely available in Europe, has started making its way to U.S. shores.

image.caption: Audi start/stop technology can be clearly seen when active.

pageElements.text: Start/stop systems, which allow engines to turn off while cars are stopped at red lights, aim to be an unobtrusive way to increase efficiency. It’s hard to argue with the logic. As an Audi ad campaign points out, turning off the engine while stopped is similar to turning off the lights when you leave a room. With the car stopped and the gearshift in neutral, a light on the dash will illuminate to let drivers know the technology is active. As soon as the clutch is depressed, the engine quickly turns back on again and normal driving resumes. This feature won’t earn you hybrid mileage, but for buyers looking for performance automobiles with a conscience, it is certainly a start.

Audi brought start/stop technology to the United States in 2009 and has since expanded its availability to include the A7, A8, Q5, and Q7. BMW offers the technology in all 1 and 3 Series models equipped with a four-cylinder engine and a manual transmission. Ford began introducing Auto Start-Stop to the 2013 Fusion with EcoBoost engine as a $295 option, granting access at a more affordable price point.

Taking the idea one step further, GM has introduced eAssist with the Buick LaCrosse and Regal and the Chevrolet Malibu Eco. You won’t hear GM say it in ads, but the technology turns cars into what is referred to as a “mild hybrid.” A battery motor takes over when the car is stopped, then returns power almost seamlessly to the traditional engine once the car has started rolling. GM's eAssist can also lend a little extra power when drivers demand heavy acceleration. Compared with a full hybrid, the fuel savings are modest, but GM hopes that it will be able to spread the versatile technology easily throughout its fleet. Full hybrids, on the other hand, typically require specialized engineering to maintain the car’s balance and drivability.

The actual fuel savings from these technologies can differ, depending on whom you ask and how you measure it, but even if you don’t notice a huge difference at the pump, these options may help you sleep easier, knowing that your daily drive melted a little less of the polar ice caps than everyone else’s.

title: Is Your Dog One of the 98%?
subTitle: We’re not just talking to Mitt Romney here: if your dog is among the 98 percent that ride unrestrained, it’s time to think that one over.
promoTitle: Is Your Dog One of the 98%?
promoTeaserSmall: We’re not just talking to Mitt Romney: if your dog rides loose in the car, you should reconsider.
promoTeaser: We’re not just talking to Mitt Romney: if your dog rides loose in the car, you should reconsider.
metaTitle: Is Your Dog One of the 98 percent that are unrestrained in the car?
metaDescription: JeanKnowsCars.com explains the importance of restraining a dog while it travels in the car with you.

pageElements.text: Mitt Romney may be the poster child for bad behavior when it comes to dogs and road trips, thanks to a long-lived story about a 1983 family trip when his family’s Irish setter rode in a crate on the roof of the station wagon. It was a real-life version of Aunt Edna in the movie National Lampoon’s Vacation, and both late-night TV comedians and animal rights groups took notice.

images.caption: "Pet lifestyle expert" Charlotte Reed and her golden retriever, Hannah, demonstrate proper use of a safety harness in a Chevrolet Equinox during Pet Day at the 2012 New York Auto Show last April. (Diane Bondareff/AP Images for Chevrolet)

pageElements.text: That story strained the boundaries of outrageousness—but it turns out that most dog owners could stand to reconsider the way they travel in cars with their pets. The organization Paws to Click, which promotes safer pet travel, says 98 percent of dogs travel unrestrained in vehicles—and that there’s an accident every eighteen minutes because of a loose animal. That adds up to an estimated 30,000 driving accidents per year.

Safety advocates warn that a 60-pound dog traveling at 35 mph can turn into the equivalent of a 2,700-pound projectile in a crash. Dogs should be secured with a harness that allows them to sit or lie down but will keep them restrained in an accident, says Paws to Click, which is related to a company that actually sells said harnesses. That doesn't mean it's not a really good idea, though!

One possible source of those accidents could be distracted driving that is caused by the presence of the dog in the car. A 2011 study by AAA and Kurgo, a pet-supply company, reported that 52 percent of surveyed drivers admitted to having petted their canine companions at some time instead of paying attention to the road, while another 17 percent of drivers said they allow the dog to sit in their lap while driving.
Other behaviors noted in the study include the mildly alarming “reaching into the back seat to interact with the dog,” along with giving the dog treats and taking a photo of the dog while driving.

Some carmakers, such as Subaru of America, offer optional pet barriers for the cargo area. The Japanese automaker even sells dog bandanas, collars and collapsible water bowls on its Web site. Subaru says seven out of ten Subaru owners have a pet.

Automakers occasionally roll out canine-friendly special models. Before it discontinued the Element, Japanese automaker Honda advertised a Dog Friendly package for the Element. It was equipped with a soft floor surface to be gentle to dogs’ legs and paws, along with a spill-resistant water bowl, a soft-sided kennel, and an integrated ramp that could be accessed with the rear tailgate down.

For now, you’ll probably have to customize your own vehicle with pet-friendly items found in pet stores or online from suppliers. Some outfitters are even selling water bowls for dogs that fit in a vehicle’s cupholder.

Bottom line: Until they learn how to drive, all four of Jean’s unruly dogs (Lou, Stella, Bob and Ray) ride in crates—inside the car, of course—during road trips, just as you see in the photo. How about yours?

title: Designing Women from Day One
subTitle: Women have had a hand in auto design from its earliest days.
promoTeaserSmall: Designing Women from Day One: You can go all the way back to the early 20th century, and there were women involved in car design.
promoTeaser: Designing Women from Day One: You can go all the way back to the early 20th century, and there were women involved in car design.
metaTitle: Designing Women from Day One, from JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Designing Women from Day One. Learn about how women have played a role in car design for more than a century but still haven't broken through the glass ceiling.

pageElements.text: Women have had a hand in auto design from way back in the earliest days of motoring.

Among the earliest known female creators of cars were Margaret E. Knight, an engineer, and her niece, Beatrice Davidson. Their K-D automobile made its debut in Brookline, Massachusetts, in 1912, according to the book A Century of Automotive Style: 100 Years of American Car Design. Unfortunately, that car wasn’t around for very long.

Miriam W. Hubbard, a banker’s daughter from Philadelphia, inspired the 1916-19 Biddle roadster. Hubbard stipulated that she wanted a sport roadster that looked like it was "going 60 mph standing still." Positively vertiginous! It had portholes in the hood, wire-spoked wheels, and V-shaped headlights, but no running boards.

Betty Thatcher is believed to be the first female designer to be hired by an automaker full time. She worked for Hudson in 1939 and designed the 1941 Hudson instrument panel and a bit of the model’s external trim.

General Motors' legendary design chief Harley Earl began bringing women aboard his design team in 1943, dubbing them his Damsels of Design. That may not be a flattering name in hindsight, but for the time, it was revolutionary enough. They worked on interiors, instrument panels, steering wheels,  and seat trim.

Yes, that was seventy long years ago, and nobody is calling the legion of professional women in the auto industry "damsels" these days--but still, here in 2012, not one major global automaker has tapped a woman to be its chief designer.

title: 2013 Ford Edge
subTitle: Its looks aren’t edgy, but it edges closer to stylishness than the average boxy people carrier.
metaTitle: 2013 Ford Edge
metaDescription: 2013 ford edge buyer's guide

pageElements.text: Ford’s Edge is all about versatility. It’s about moving beyond the carpool mindset and going for something more appealing to drive. Its looks are on the curvy side, distancing it from the boxy minivan aesthetic, yet it still has the kind of interior space a cargo- and kid-carrying family will appreciate. The Edge can be fitted with a turbocharged four-cylinder or one of two V6 choices. With the four, fuel economy is 21 mpg in the city and an impressive 30 mpg on the highway, while the V6s offer 19 mpg in town and 26 or 27 mpg on the highway. All-wheel drive is an option for all models; it cuts fuel economy by about 2 mpg.

The Edge offers well-tuned and responsive steering, along with some of the latest in safety technology: roll stability control, side air curtains for the first and second rows of seats, and blind-spot mirrors. A Blind Spot Information System is optional. Ford’s Sync multimedia system and MyFord Touch touchscreen interface are both available on every Edge except for the base model, but prepare for a learning curve. The top-end Edge, the Sport, has the biggest V6 (305 horsepower) and lots of upscale goodies, including paddle shifters for the six-speed automatic transmission, charcoal leather-trimmed seats with metallic silver inserts, a Sony audio system with HD radio, six-way heated power seats, 22-inch polished aluminum wheels with black spokes, and chrome oval dual exhaust. It also comes with a $10,000 higher price than the $27,525 of the base Edge, starting at $37,110.

title: 2013 Ford C-Max Hybrid
subTitle: Ford tosses down the hybrid gauntlet with its new model, which gets 47 miles per gallon both in town and on the highway.
metaTitle: 2013 Ford C-Max
metaDescription: 2013 ford c-max hybrid buyer's guide

pageElements.text: Hybrids are settling into the mainstream. The proof comes from Ford’s all-new C-Max Hybrid and Energi. The compact car is cute in the current Ford style, with wedgy shaping and a toothy grille, but its main selling point is fuel economy. It is rated at 47 mpg both in town and on the highway—which Ford hastens to point out is 7 mpg better than the Toyota Prius v’s highway numbers. The C-Max has a lithium-ion battery that recharges when the gasoline engine is in use; plus, there’s regenerative braking—recycling at its least onerous—which recaptures up to 95 percent of the energy used in braking and uses it to recharge the battery. The C-Max is not only efficient; it also responds to the eco-conscious aesthetic by using a greenery theme in its Smartgauge display, which displays more leaves and vines as a “visual reward” when a driver is more efficient in his or her driving habits. The C-Max’s popular price, starting just over $25,000—lower than its closest rival, the Toyota Prius, and some $10,000 cheaper than the Chevrolet Volt and the Nissan Leaf—will help it win fans, as will its uncontroversial styling. The fact that you can drive the plug-in Energi at speeds up to 85 mph on electrical power alone should electrify the highway commuter crowd. But the number-one drawing card will be its efficiency in a time of insecure gasoline prices.

Competitors:
1.	Toyota Prius v
2.	Toyota Prius III


Cool Tech items
1. Smartgauge display shows a leafy vine that gets lusher the more efficiently the car is driven
2. Regenerative braking and Brake Coach to help get the most out of it
3. ECO Cruise highway cruise control technology

Looks:
1. In-floor storage in second row


New for 2013 
1. All-new model


Fun-O-Meter: 5

title: 2013 Ford Explorer
subTitle: All-purpose SUV has crossed over into crossover territory, and the crowds love it more than ever.
metaTitle: 2013 Ford Explorer Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Ford Explorer Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Ford Explorer is a huge seller and a familiar sight on the roads of America. Long a traditional rear-wheel-drive SUV, the Explorer was completely remade for 2011 into a front-wheel-drive/all-wheel-drive crossover. It even comes with the option of a four-cylinder engine. That hasn’t changed its reputation as a go-anywhere utility vehicle, though. Teamed with all-wheel drive on V-6-powered models is Ford’s optional Terrain Management. This system lets you dial in the vehicle’s response to the surfaces on which you’re traveling, using pictograms for grass/gravel/snow, sand, mud/ruts, or normal. There’s also Hill Descent Control, which takes over the braking duties when you go downhill, so you can concentrate on steering. Other helpful features include adaptive cruise control, a blind-spot warning system, and parking assist. The Explorer Sport model gives you both more power and more style, with 350 horsepower from a twin-turbo V-6 engine, a set of twenty-inch wheels, and contrast stitching on the seats. As for fuel economy, you can get 28 mpg on the highway, but only if you forgo all-wheel drive and get the four-cylinder engine. With the V-6 and AWD, you’ll get 23 mpg on the highway, and the Explorer Sport tops out at 22 mpg highway. It’s not the most exciting product on the market, either to drive or to look at—but for those who want to haul stuff, carry up to seven people, and feel more like a rugged adventurer than a boring commuter, the Explorer is a popular choice.

Fun-O-Meter:
6.5

Competitors:
1. Honda Pilot
2. Toyota Highlander
3. Jeep Grand Cherokee
4. Chevrolet Traverse

Cool Tech Items:
1. Optional Terrain Management System that lets you dial in terrain pictograms for sand, mud/ruts, grass/gravel/snow, or normal; it then adjusts torque and throttle settings.
2. Curve Control slows the vehicle by up to 10 mph if a curve is being taken too fast.
3. Inflatable rear seatbelts (optional).

Looks:
1. Power folding third-row seat folds flat into floor (optional).
2. Two-tone leather and contrasting stitching on the seats in Explorer Sport.

New for 2013:
1. Lane-keeping assist.
2. Heated steering wheel.
3. Power tilting/telescoping steering wheel.

title: Under Five Feet in the Driver's Seat
promoTitle: Under Five Feet in the Driver's Seat
promoTeaserSmall: One size doesn't always fit all. How does an educated, sophisticated, but extremely petite driver cope?
promoTeaser: One size doesn't always fit all. How does an educated, sophisticated, but extremely petite driver cope?
metaTitle: Under Five Feet in the Driver's Seat
metaDescription: Under Five Feet in the Driver's Seat. Driving can be particularly challenging for people under 5'5". Learn why at JeanKnowsCars.com

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

I am Gabrielle Taylor George, and I graduated in 2011 from Pioneer High School in Ann Arbor, Michigan, the city I was born and raised in. The words that describe me are DRIVE, determination, enterprise, initiative, eagerness, motivation, resolve, enthusiasm, hunger, commitment, sense of purpose. I have this crazy dream to become a great photographer and to have studios all over. I believe that we're put on this planet to enjoy life, that we have everything we would ever need to dream big, and that we can achieve the dream. I grasp the concept of first working for it, then deserving it. I believe it's up to you to take the wheel of the car that represents you and drive down that dark road—only seeing so much of what's ahead, not knowing but continuing anyway because there is no fear. Carry on and expect the best. When the worst comes around, keep driving.  And so far, I’ve only landed in jobs that support my dreams. I don’t want to stop for anybody.

pageElements.text: Most Embarrassing Moment Ever. 1981, Great Falls, Virginia. I was thirteen; four feet, eleven inches tall; considerably rotund; and remarkably unathletic. Great Falls—now an enclave of substantial wealth—was then a rural Virginia community, and some of us really did have to walk a mile in the sun or snow to get to our bus stop. One cold day, one of the Klett boys—cute high schoolers who lived down the road—stopped his white Ford Bronco and asked if I wanted a ride home. My heart a bit aflutter, I tried to get in, but the Bronco lacked a running board for the vertically challenged. Between my short legs, girth, and complete lack of flexibility, I couldn’t step up into the car. I had to be hauled into the Bronco like a beached whale…and I wanted to die, right then and there. I have hated Broncos and that lack of a running board ever since.

Thirty years later, very much because of that moment, my girth is significantly reduced, my flexibility notably improved. My height, however, remains unchanged, and my contentious relationship with the automobile thus continues. Most vehicles are designed with the “average male” in mind: five feet, nine inches and 172 pounds. Women? Secondary consideration. Under five feet tall and 100 pounds? Not under consideration at all, unless we’re talking child car seats.
Try functioning in a driver’s seat when you’re the size of a fifth grader.

images.caption: Sitting up close for comfort can put you too close to the dash--and the sunshade.
Good thing there are tilting and telescoping steering wheels, but that's not always enough.
Then there's the issue of getting the door closed once you're situated.
Cars are not necessarily one size fits all, that's for sure.

pageElements.text:
Yet, seats are the battleground. Try functioning in a driver’s seat when you’re the size of a fifth grader. Driving my mother’s Audi always reminds me of sitting in a wheelbarrow: I can’t see the hood, but I have a great view of the sky. Depressing the clutch in that car is a bit of a trick: full leg extension required, it becomes quite the quad workout. In other cars, it’s not the distance to the pedals, it’s the overall configuration of the vehicle. Once, in a loaner Accord, I could not for the life of me figure out where the speedometer was located. I got on the highway with great trepidation. What if I got pulled over?</br>
</br>
“Excuse me, ma’am. Do you know how fast you were going?”</br>
“No, officer. This car has no speedometer…”</br>
</br>
The speedometer, my incredulous salesman later informed me, was an LED display. The top of the steering wheel, directly level with my eyes, obviously blocked more than my view of the road.

I do not have these issues in my Odyssey—I can (barely) see the hood and reach the pedals, and the speedometer is in full view. However, the seat is so far forward that there is not a lot of clearance between my body and the vehicle parts. I live in fear of the airbag. My breasts have an intimate relationship with the steering wheel; only a couple of inches of distance maintain a more proper relationship between the wheel and my thighs. It is a tight fit. My apologies to the many average male valets who have jauntily jumped into the driver’s seat after me, only to emasculate themselves. Being average height seems to have its hazards, too.

title: Car Seats: Am I Doing This Right?
promoTitle: Car Seats: Am I Doing This Right?
promoTeaserSmall: First-time mom faces the infant car seat challenge--and prevails.
promoTeaser: First-time mom faces the infant car seat challenge--and prevails.
metaTitle: Car Seats: Am I Doing This Right? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Car Seats: Am I Doing This Right? Jean Knows Cars contributor and first-time mom learns how to buy and install an infant car seat. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: You might think shopping for a car seat would be easy for an automotive writer, but I assure you, it's not.

There are more than 100 models of car seats on the market, and they more or less all do the same thing. Pre-pregnancy, I probably would have just eyeballed a product and picked the model with the best balance of attractive packaging and price. However, something about expecting a child for the first time makes even so-called experts second-guess their instincts and decision-making skills and question every purchase.

Adding to the pressure was the assurance from another expectant mom in my childbirth class that this was one of the most important decisions I would be making for my child. The message is clear: choose the wrong car seat, and my baby could die.

Google, which theoretically should make researching easier, actually makes things worse. Search strings became my new forte, and they give me powerful new analytical skills, which I seem to use only when it comes to selecting baby gear. Complicated Excel spreadsheets with charts and rating systems were drafted. Anonymous questions were posted on BabyCenter.com, and e-mails were sent to product manufacturers. Perhaps too much weight and deference was given to reviewers with eyebrow-raising names like "Ms_MeowMeow."

Despite coming into the process with a better-than-average understanding of where to look for information, online shopping was a failure. I couldn't manage the dozen or so windows crowding my tiny laptop screen while cross-checking model numbers with "professional" reviews from bloggers and parenting sites, and then verifying with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration if it had been recalled or not. With my due date fast approaching, I shut my computer and headed over to the local baby mart.
But it didn’t get any easier.

I was confronted with a wall of choices. Each bulbous seat was clothed in epileptic-fit-inducing hot pink and giraffe-printed fabrics, each competing to out-bulk, out-plasticize, and out-bling the next. The minimalist in me (read: cheapskate) flirted with the idea of getting an all-in-one car seat that would take my soon-to-be-born daughter from birth to toddlerhood. But that idea was nixed by the salesperson, who swore I wouldn’t want to wake a napping baby to move her from the stroller to the car seat every time.
"Go with the infant seat," she insisted.

That meant choosing a base with a car seat that could be detached and carried by its handle into the house or attached to a stroller. The kicker was that the car seat would work for six months at most before I'd have to repeat the agonizing process of finding yet another car seat when my daughter exceeds the twenty-two or thirty-pound weight limit most infant seats provide.
It also turns out that choosing a car seat directly influences the stroller you get, forcing you to make two important decisions at once. But which do you pick first? The car seat or the stroller?

Luckily, fate decided for me. I jumped on a promotion that offered a free car seat with a purchase of a Britax B-Ready stroller, which I was already eyeing. There were two Britax car seats available, but the Chaperone was the bigger, more expensive option touting something called "recoil protection." I didn’t know what that was, but I was positive my newborn would need it.
Online reviews mentioned that the Chaperone was significantly longer than the B-Safe, which made me hesitate on the "add to cart" button.
"Get the bigger one," insisted my husband, clearly looking just to maximize the benefit of the free promotion.

But bigger wasn’t better when it came to trying to fit it into our 2008 Subaru Outback. As the online reviewer warned, it didn’t fit our mid-size car. The only way it would sit on the bench is if both front seats were adjusted all the way forward, which would definitely be safe for our child because we wouldn’t be able to fit in the car or drive anywhere.
Back the Chaperone went to Amazon, with return shipping fees eating into our promotional savings. A few days later, the smaller, cheaper B-Safe arrived.

And the second one didn’t seem to fit, either. While technically we could  squeeze it in the middle seat of the second row, we struggled to get the seatbelt tight enough. Tension seemed to come solely from the front driver and passenger seats pressing tight against the car seat, pinning it in place. Was this normal? Were we doing this right?
 
Having bought a B-Ready stroller, I was more or less stuck with this car seat, since Britax strollers only accommodate Britax car seats. So rather than turn to Google, I dialed up the local Car Seat Lady for validation.

Sue Emery is a certified child passenger safety technician, who has spent the past twenty years teaching parents in the Seattle area how to buy and properly install car seats in their vehicles. She reassured me that I didn’t make a huge mistake
"Every car seat on the market is a perfect car seat," Emery said, effectively making the all-nighter I pulled on Consumer Reports a waste of time. "But not every car seat fits every car."
Of this, I was painfully aware.
She continued, "Even if the car seat technically fits the car, it may not fit it with the driver and front passenger in it."

Since car seats are regulated and car companies independently crash test their car seats, a parent should feel confident that it will protect her child in a crash – as long as it’s installed correctly. But nine times out of ten, it’s not. This means parents should be shopping for car seat by size and fit, not by price, color, or stroller compatibility, as I did.
Apparently, the time to consult the car seat lady is before you make your purchase.

Within twenty minutes of her free consultation in the parking lot at my apartment, she taught me how to adjust the base so it fit on the bench seat and install the car seat with room for my husband and me to still fit comfortably in the front row. And I only broke two nails in the process.

Just as important were her recommendations for convertible seats that would fit my car when my daughter outgrew her infant carrier seat, which will cut my shopping time down to nothing. But next on my list is picking out the best car seat mirror so I can keep an eye on my little munchkin while I’m behind the wheel. Back to Google, for another round of overanalyzing.

images.caption: Freshly purchased car seat, ready to install.
Owner's manual is a good place to start.
The base goes in first.
Attaching it securely is the most important step.
Now I can add the removable part, where my daughter will ride.
And I'm ready!

title: Piano Goes Forte
subTitle: Ferrari Testarossa's sleek looks inspire the design of this baby grand.
promoTeaserSmall: Here’s a piano that will make you want to play the Minute Waltz in half the time.
promoTeaser: Here’s a piano that will make you want to play the Minute Waltz in half the time.
metaTitle: Piano Goes Forte
metaDescription: Piano Goes Forte. Jean Knows Cars has a look at a piano designed to look like the vintage Ferrari Testa Rossa.

contributors.bio: When people ask me how I started writing about cars, I tell them I'm from Detroit. I tell them about my father, who was a Chrysler engineer, and the crazy cars he would bring home to test drive. But before I discovered the glamorous life of an automotive journalist, I was a writer living in the Motor City, covering music and art in the Nineties. Things changed when I became curious about the industry that made the city tick and interned at AutoWeek magazine. I moved to New York City in 2003, where I’ve worked as a freelance writer for almost a decade. I’ve written for more than 100 magazines, newspapers, and websites, including the New York Times, Rolling Stone, Forbes, Jay-z’s Life and Times, Vibe, Automobile Magazine, AutoWeek and the Detroit Free Press. I finished an MFA in creative writing at the New School this year. I live with two car buffs, Lee Quiñones and our four-year-old son, who both think what I do is pretty cool.

pageElements.text: Resinno Design’s Grand Rossa just might be the Ferrari of pianos. Certainly that is the maker's intention. The 1957 Testa Rossa inspired the design of this one-of-a-kind Yamaha piano, currently on display in a Ferrari showroom in Tampa Bay, Florida. The piano legs are painted in actual Ferrari red Rosso Corsa factory paint. The front legs form semi-helixes in the likeness of the Testa Rossa’s sleek dimensions, and the arch has the contours of a Ferrari physique. The Testa Rossa’s interior is re-created in the bench’s hand-stitched pattern.

Justin Elliott is the co-founder of Resinno, a firm that makes fine pianos into high art. Not only a master craftsman but a possessor of that prized attribute of musicians that is perfect pitch, Elliott has tweaked pianos for such artists as Elton John, Chick Corea and Alicia Keys. With this latest work, the 27-year-old designer has found a way to merge his passion for Italian sports cars with his specialization in musical precision.  “I’ve always loved cars and concepts,” he says.” I decided to design the Testa Rossa according to the curves and accents of the car.”

To incorporate the Ferrari spirit into the piano, he studied the engineering of the car’s exhaust notes and compared the process to the craft of making instruments. “The grand masters who tuned engines would tune it by ear, and you can do the same thing with wood.”

He used Neodymium magnets instead of fasteners to achieve fullness in sound. The red surfaces are especially slick, due to ten coats of paint, which are hand rubbed and buffed. “I use the exact same technique as an instrument maker. It’s hand rubbed, all wood, nothing’s metal, which accounts for the tonality and richness.”

Resinno Design can recreate the design on different kinds of pianos and plans to produce a limited edition run of ten Testa Rossa pianos. Each piano takes about three months to complete by the team of seven that work for the company in Clearwater, Florida. The design alone is $55,000. Add that to the cost of the piano at $97,000, and the total comes to $152,000.

title: 2013 Acura ILX
subTitle: Acura’s entry-level sedan: luxury for the everyman
metaTitle: 2013 Acura ILX -  Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Acura ILX Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The 2013 ILX sedan aims to offer lots of luxury in a small package. Although not much bigger than the Honda Civic, the ILX holds up better on bumpy roads. The ILX’s smooth plastic interior isn’t as highbrow as some competitors', but it certainly doesn’t grate the eyes. Keyless entry and ignition, push-button start, and a power moonroof come standard, but the real draw is the standard Pandora Internet radio interface. Acura’s first offering to the entry-level luxury market comes with three powertrain options: a five-speed automatic, a more exciting six-speed manual transmission, and a 111-horsepower hybrid. The hybrid makes up for its lack of punch with an impressive 39 mpg in the city, which might be enough to make you embrace the gridlock on your morning commute. Even the base ILX is more fuel-efficient than the rest of Acura’s fleet. The ILX’s styling may not turn heads, and for the money (around $30,000), you may as well check out the peppier Acura TSX, but the ILX offers a touch of sophistication without the sticker shock usually associated with a luxury brand.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Audi A3
2.Buick Verano
3. Lexus CT200h

Cool Tech:
1. Hybrid model gets almost 40 mpg city.
2. Pandora Internet radio interface.

Looks:
1. Sleeker styling than the rest of Acura’s fleet.
2. Interior available in black or cream.

New for 2013:
1. All-new model.
2. Acura’s first small car designed for the North American market.

title: 2013 Acura MDX
subTitle: The MDX can fit everything you own and still make it around tight corners.
metaTitle: 2013 Acura MDX Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Acura MDX Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The 2013 MDX – no changes from last year’s model – is Acura’s bestselling SUV for a reason. It seats seven, can tow up to 5,000 pounds, and has more cargo space than any other car in Acura’s lineup. It also handles like a much smaller car, with Acura’s impressive all-wheel-drive system to help it around corners. The MDX’s 3.7-liter V-6 engine gives it plenty of power, and a new six-speed automatic transmission helps it achieve 21 mpg on the highway and 16 mpg in the city, so it's more fuel-efficient than previous models. The MDX’s interior isn’t quite cutting edge, but it does handle the task of making a seven-seater feel spacious and comfortable.  With spacious front seats, a reclining second row, and an available rear video monitor, the MDX could be the answer for moms who shun the minivan. This utilitarian vehicle is not for everyone, however. With a base price range topping out just above $55,000 and a taste for premium fuel, the MDX makes you pay for everything you get. With this car’s versatility, the price may just be worth it.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. BMW X5
2. Buick Enclave
3. Volvo XC90

Cool Tech:
1. SH-AWD and IDS make for smooth driving.
2. Available DVD player and 115-volt power outlet.

Looks:
1. Spacious, leather-trimmed interior.
2. Power moonroof and rear privacy glass.

title: 2013 Acura RDX
subTitle: The new and improved RDX is a better car in almost every way.
metaTitle: 2013 Acura RDX Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Acura RDX Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The 2013 RDX is a full reboot from earlier models, and in this case change is good. This crossover (longer than last year’s model but still smaller than Acura’s bestselling MDX) has more space inside and has lost the unfortunate hard plastic interior of 2012. Instead, the new model has an MDX-like smooth plastic interior and classy beige seats. On the outside, the RDX looks like a mini-me of the seven-passenger MDX, but the association is by no means damaging. More important, a smaller V-6 engine is both more powerful and more fuel-efficient than the old RDX, coming in at 19 to 20 mpg city, 27 to 28 mpg highway. The new RDX is also better around corners and smoother over bumps. Better yet, it received top scores for safety from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. The basic package comes with heated seats, a power moonroof, Bluetooth connectivity, and a USB audio input so that you never have to listen to radio commercials again. All this at a much lower price point than its big brother the MDX. So, what’s not to like? Not much. Less space than some larger crossovers and occasionally jerky shifts, but the new RDX is a huge improvement over older models, and it won’t leave you wanting more.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Audi Q5
2. BMW X3
3. Lexus RX

Cool Tech:
1. New brake system earned RDX the highest possible safety scores.
2. Available Pandora Internet radio connectivity.

Looks:
1. New, smoother plastic interior.
2. Power moonroof.

New for 2013:
1. New, smoother exterior design.
2. More powerful and efficient 3.5-liter V-6 engine.

title: 2013 Acura RL
subTitle: The RL is an old lion on its way out.
metaTitle: 2013 Acura RL Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Acura RL Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The RL sports the same 3.7-liter V-6 engine as Acura’s TL, with plenty of power for a sedan, and the same all-wheel-drive system helps them around corners. The RL is clearly the more sedate of the two and draws in older buyers with its cushy interior. More spacious than any other Acura sedan, the RL has room for passengers to stretch out. It benefits from a sleek looking dash and information display, although the navigation system itself could use an update. Smooth leather seats come standard, as do keyless entry and a USB port and auxiliary jack for MP3 players. Change is in the air for the RL, however. After a long history as Acura’s respectable, refined sedan, the RL will become the 2014 RLX, for sale in early 2013. The new model will be bigger and heavier, and will come in a “sport hybrid” model, which Acura expects to achieve 30 mpg – a huge improvement over the current model’s 24 mpg on the highway. The RL provides more than enough comfort and drivability for its nearly $50,000 price point, but it could use a touch more excitement, which is probably exactly what the RLX will have in store.
Fun-O-Meter: 4

Competitors:
1. BMW 5 Series
2. Lincoln MKS
3. Mercedes-Benz E-Class

Cool Tech:
1. Available rearview camera and rear parking sensors.
2. XM radio with USB and auxiliary jack.

Looks:
1. Smooth leather seats.
2. Illuminated exterior door handles.

New for 2012:
1. No new RL until the 2014 RLX.
2. 2014 RLX will be a complete redesign.

title: 2013 Acura TL
subTitle: A redesigned TL is less distinctive, less controversial
metaTitle: 2013 Acura TL Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Acura TL

pageElements.text: The 2013 TL has no changes from the 2012 model, perhaps because 2012 was the TL’s best year in recent memory. The redesigned front end is much more appealing, with changes to the grille and the front and rear bumpers. Previous TLs sported a love-it-or-hate-it beak-like snout; the new incarnation is much more refined. The real changes are on the outside, but the TL does now offer optional creamy Milano leather seats. The TL allows drivers to choose between two engines: 280-horsepower V-6 with a six-speed automatic transmission or a 305-horsepower engine with a six-speed manual transmission. If you know your way around a clutch, the manual is refreshingly smooth. The smaller engine is an improvement over previous five-cylinder models, but the 300-horsepower manual has more pickup and handles tight turns better than the automatic. The TL’s fuel economy is respectable at 17 to 20 mpg city and 25 to 29 mpg highway. Like the RL, the TL has a dated navigation system and cluttered climate and audio controls. Despite minor deficiencies, the redesign gracefully handled most of the TL’s problems, leaving behind a car that both looks and feels more like luxury.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Audi A4/S4
2. Infiniti G37
3. Cadillac CTS

Cool Tech:
1. Six-speed automatic boosts fuel economy.
2. All-wheel drive provides smooth handling.

Looks:
1. Exterior redesign more broadly appealing.
2. Available contrasting Euro-style stitching on seats and trim.

title: Turn Your Car Into A WiFi Hotspot
promoTitle: Turn Your Car Into A WiFi Hotspot
promoTeaserSmall: As the world grows ever more connected, carmakers are here to answer the call.
promoTeaser: As the world grows ever more connected, carmakers are here to answer the call.
metaTitle: Turn Your Car Into A WiFi Hotspot - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Turn Your Car Into A WiFi Hotspot
metaDescription: Turn Your Car Into A WiFi Hotspot: Find out how some auto manufacturers are adding WiFi hotspots as an option in their vehicles.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Cars that act as mobile WiFi hotspots are growing common. Audi offers the technology in all models except the A3, TT and R8. Jeep, BMW, Mercedes-Benz, and Ford offer it as an option throughout their fleets. Drivers not lucky enough to have roving WiFi in place when they buy a car can buy after-market routers online (Amazon’s got them) and turn even a car on its last legs into a WiFi palace. AutoNet is a popular provider of the routers, which run $200-$400 at online retailers.

The Audi technology allows up to eight devices to connect to the hotspot, enough for each passenger to connect two devices, depending on the car. Audi claims that the connection is speedy enough to stream music to the car’s stereo.

The WiFi option is best for vehicles that often carry passengers, since drivers obviously shouldn’t surf the web from behind the wheel. But if the kids have developed a taste for Phineas and Ferb episodes streamed from the iPad, this could be a lifesaver. It should come as no surprise to us who have been bled dry by smartphone bills that the WiFi won’t work without a subscription to a data plan. New cars often come with a free trial, but once that runs out you’ll pay around $30 a month for the sweet privilege of letting other people stream video in your car.

title: Teardrop Campers
subTitle: Take your good taste on a road trip!
promoTeaserSmall: These are the little gems of the highway: vintage style in tiny packages that you can go camping in.
promoTeaser: These are the little gems of the highway: vintage style in tiny packages that you can go camping in.
metaTitle: Teardrop Campers: Small Is Beautiful - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Teardrop campers: Small Is Beautiful. Teardrops are tiny gems of construction that you can make yourself, rent, or buy, then tow behind even a small car. Read about them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Have you ever heard of a teardrop trailer? One look at one, and you'll understand where they got the name. They're small, adorable, and still available to buy today.

But they have a long history. Teardrop trailers enjoyed their first success as the United States was recovering from the Great Depression, a time when having a car with a trailer meant mobility and freedom. Before there was airfare for the masses, but after the affinity for comfort was ingrained in the national psyche, these little charmers ruled the road for several decades.

Do-it-yourself plans once graced the pages of lifestyle magazines, and you can still buy trailer plans for around $20 (right). Add parts, and the whole project will set you back about $700. While campers flourished, the U.S. highway system expanded, and road trips became part of the American experience. Today, with high gas prices causing buyers to think twice before buying a Winnebago and a stalled economy putting the kibosh on luxury vacations, teardrop campers have enjoyed a recent resurgence in popularity.

Where Can You Get One?

A teardrop camper is typically small and aerodynamic, with a double bed in the cabin and a camp kitchen hidden in a hatchback-like rear storage area. Many are light enough to be towed behind any car you care to hitch them to. MiniTears specializes in custom-built trailers for Mini Coopers, and the website of manufacturer Little Guy features a picture of a tiny trailer being pulled behind ultracompact cars. And no wonder: the Little Guy Rascal (right) boasts diminutive interior measurements of 37.5 inches high, 44.5 inches wide, and 88 inches long.

Trailers can cost about $10,000 to $12,000 new or a few thousand dollars less when used, but they can also cost much more. For example, a beautifully crafted Custom Teardrop Camping Trailer from outdoor outfitter Orvis (right) comes with a sapele and mahogany body, a double bed, and a freshwater tank and faucet, priced at $29,995. If you can’t afford to spend tens of thousands on something without a motor, many dealers will rent the campers at rates that average $300 a week: try Vacations in a Can in California, or Hitch and Go Adventures in Texas, or Google "teardrop camper rental" for one nearer you. But if you want to maximize your retro street cred, find a vintage teardrop from the movement’s post-Depression-era heyday, hitch it behind a classic Chevrolet, and hit the open road.

Orvis Custom Teardrop Camping Trailer, inside.
Orvis Custom Teardrop Camping Trailer has a sapele and mahogany body.
Little Guy Rascal Teardrop trailer.
Charming interior of the Little Guy trailer.

title: Panels Put the Art in Smart
promoTitle: Panels Put the Art in Smart
promoTeaserSmall: Smart takes a cue from Pinterest, Facebook, and other transitory media with changeable body looks.
promoTeaser: Smart takes a cue from Pinterest, Facebook, and other transitory media with changeable body looks.
metaTitle: Smart Body Panels - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Smart has introduced a way for owners to personalize the body panels of their cars with body wrap kits. Read all about it and see images on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Smart has had trouble gaining traction in the U.S. market, despite its undeniable practicality as a city car. Smart was introduced to the U.S. in 2008 and enjoyed a year of strong sales with distributor Penske. The brand’s second year,  sales fell by 41 percent, however, and third-year numbers were 66 percent below the previous year. Daimler took over distribution and marketing for the brand in 2011 and has since seen ten consecutive months of “year-over-year sales increases,” according to the automaker. A little over a year ago, Smart launched its Uncar ad campaign, and the brand is working that edginess in quest of a growing customer base.

The microcar has an impressive commitment to personalization, offering dozens of colorful wrap kits to make your car stand out from the crowd. Available for browsing on the Smart USA website are choices from houndstooth to camo to plaid, not to mention a few designs reminiscent of MS Paint scribblings. Buying a stock wrap kit for your car might feel a little like buying art from Ikea, but Smart can also create a body wrap from your original design.  If permanent car modifications aren’t your style, you can make temporary attitude adjustments to your smart by switching the interchangeable body panels, allowing you to change your car’s exterior color on a whim.

images.caption: Go ahead, get ideas for design and then try them out on your Smart Fortwo.
Take two: they're small.

pageElements.text: A full set of panels – don’t worry, they’re 100 percent recyclable – will run you $900 to $1,400, depending on the color and where you buy them. Smart owners can save money (and let’s face it, if you’re buying a $13,000 car you’re not rolling in it) by arranging panel swaps over online forums like SmartCarofAmerica.com, Smart451.com, and Smartmadnessforum.com. Although dealers can switch out panels for you, websites also offer instructions for the do-it-yourself types.

It remains to be seen whether the potential for personalization will be enough to give Smart a new spring in its step, but when we called a Smart dealership to check prices, they didn’t even realize they sold the panels and said no one had ever asked for them.

title: Name-Brand Stereos with Surround Sound
promoTeaserSmall: If you’re driving around in a fifteen-year-old car with a tape deck and a finicky AM/FM radio, you’re missing out.
promoTeaser: If you’re driving around in a fifteen-year-old car with a tape deck and a finicky AM/FM radio, you’re missing out.

metaDescription: Name-Brand Stereos with Surround Sound: Learn more out how auto manufacturers are integration high-end audio systems and name brand stereos into their cars from the factory at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: CD players are practically a thing of the past, replaced by USB ports to hook up iPods and in-car hard drives that allow your personal music collection to go wherever you go. The next step in the sound system arms race is the proliferation of name-brand stereos as a top-of-the-line option in many cars.

Several carmakers are already in on the game. Dr. Dre became Chrysler’s second rap star spokesperson when he appeared in an ad introducing the Chrysler 300S with Beats by Dre audio system. The 2013 Fiat 500 Turbo will also showcase Beats by Dre. Audi offers an optional Bang & Olufsen stereo for the low, low price of $850. That configuration boasts nineteen – nineteen! – speakers in the A8, including spaceship-like tweeters that rise from the dashboard.

The Bang & Olufsen setup essentially turns the car into a private concert venue, providing you’ve got high-quality music on your iPod and not illegally downloaded swill. Pirated music is typically downloaded as a small file to make it more manageable for your computer and harder for enforcement agencies to trace, but this also means that you lose the “it sounds like they’re standing right next to me!” moment that larger, higher quality (read: legally acquired) files can inspire. We recommend you pony up for legal tunes if you’re going to spend hundreds on a swanky in-car stereo.

images.caption: 2013 Fiat 500 Turbo is getting Dr. Dre's Beats audio system.
That elegant but edgy Dre look, well known from the headphone product line, makes it inside the Fiat.
2012 Beetle with Fender audio goes for basic black.
Fender name already makes everything sound better.

pageElements.text: Volkswagen has gone even further and created an entire special edition Beetle inspired by Fender. The new Beetle’s design is a throwback to the 60’s and 70’s era Bugs. It’s painted metallic black and sports a seriously cool starburst-trimmed dash, a nod to your inner rock star. As far as we’re concerned, the Fender Beetle hasn’t reached its true potential until you’ve played the Grateful Dead’s Woodstock performance (originally blasted through a stack of tie-dyed Fender amps) while driving through the sunshine-y countryside. You can pretend it’s 1969 again, but this time the cars are better.

title: Chevrolet Volt: Remote Start Auto Heated Seats
promoTitle: Chevrolet Volt: Remote Start Auto Heated Seats
promoTeaserSmall: Thanks to the Remote Start feature, your Volt can be warm and toasty before you even open the door.
promoTeaser: Thanks to the Remote Start feature, your Volt can be warm and toasty before you even open the door.
keywords: Chevrolet Volt: Remote Start Auto Heated Seats
metaTitle: Chevrolet Volt: Remote Start Auto Heated Seats - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Chevrolet Volt: Remote Start Auto Heated Seats
metaDescription: Chevrolet Volt: Remote Start Auto Heated Seats. Learn about the remote start and auto heated seats in the new Chevy Volt at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: Technology oozes out of the Chevy Volt even before you open the car door. Thanks to the Remote Start feature, your extended range electric vehicle can be ready and waiting for you with the cabin temperature already acclimated to the weather. Using remote start function on the Volt’s smartphone app or your key fob, you can warm up the vehicle 10 minutes before you need to leave the house. The vehicle will automatically heat the cabin climate if it’s cold outside or cool it down on hot days using your last temperature settings. This means you won’t have to shiver on chilly early mornings or sweat through your silk blouse on sweltering afternoons--at least not in your car. You can also configure the Volt’s preferences using the in-dash display to have the heated seats turn on whenever you use remote start to ensure toasty buns on the way to the office.

Besides the benefit of a smooth transition to a cozy car environment, you may also be saving energy. Preconditioning your cabin temperature while your car is still plugged into a charging station means you won’t blast the air conditioning or hot air the second you hit the road, which is like throwing money down the drain. Using AC and heat draws a lot of electricity from the lithium-ion battery, which could better be used to propel the car another few miles. And the longer you go using all electricity means fewer trips to the gas station and more dollars in your wallet.
$39,145. Remote start comes standard on the Volt.

title: Ford Fiesta: Sync Services with Sync Destinations
promoTitle: Ford Fiesta: Sync Services with Sync Destinations
promoTeaserSmall: Ford's Sync Destination is the smart way to get where you need to go in your Fiesta.
promoTeaser: Ford's Sync Destination is the smart way to get where you need to go in your Fiesta.
metaTitle: Ford Fiesta: Sync Services with Sync Destinations - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Ford Fiesta: Sync Services with Sync Destinations: Learn more about the Ford Fiesta Sync services and Ford's Sync Destinations app at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: A lot of navigation apps will tell you how long it’s going to take to get where you’re going, but Ford’s Sync Destinations app  can tell you how long it will take if you leave a couple of hours from now. When you opt for Sync, Ford’s voice-control platform, you’ll get Sync Services free for three years. You can use Sync Services to get turn-by-turn directions in the car, and you also get access one of the more clever travel and traffic mobile apps on the market for free.

Powered by Inrix, Sync Destinations uses historical traffic data and takes into account local events, weather, and sporting events to help you figure out the best time to leave for your destination. From the contact list on your iPhone or Android device, you can enter up to 25 destinations or search within the app for a business listing. The app has a “Send to Sync” button that queues up turn-by-turn directions for you to download when you start the car, or you can use AppLink voice commands to retrieve the information from your phone. Sync Destinations makes it easy to manage the carpool or survive running a long day of errands because it will show you when you’ll arrive at each saved destination if you leave immediately. It can also tell if the commute will get better or worse if you adjust your departure time. But it would be nice if it went one step further and told you the optimal order in which to make each stop.
$295. Sync services is free for three years, $60 per year thereafter.

title: Honda CR-V Standard Text-to-Voice Capability
promoTeaserSmall: The CR-V's text-to-voice capability makes receiving a text less of a guilty pleasure.
promoTeaser: The CR-V's text-to-voice capability makes receiving a text less of a guilty pleasure.
metaTitle: Honda CR-V: Standard text-to-voice capability for text messages (SMS Text Messaging) - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Honda CR-V Standard Text-to-Voice Capability. Learn more about how Honda has introduced a text-to-voice feature in their new CR-V at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: Receiving a text message while you’re behind a wheel is like having an itch that you shouldn’t scratch. As a kind of automated--and legal--back scratcher, Honda includes an SMS voice-to-text function that can read out loud the texts you receive while you’re driving in the CR-V. Using your smartphone and CR-V Bluetooth connectivity, you’ll see alerts on the Intelligent Multi-Information Display (i-MID) or in-dash navigation screen when you receive a text message. With your steering wheel controls, you can choose to listen to the messages over the vehicle’s audio system. While you won’t be able to send a custom message, you’ll have the option to reply to the SMS with one of six pre-written responses. This clever little feature makes it possible for you to listen to text messages the second you receive them without even touching your phone. After all, not everyone has Siri. The only hard part will be finding a phone that is compatible with this technology. Only a handful of BlackBerry and Android devices have the required Message Access Profile (MAP) Bluetooth profile that supports this vehicle’s systems integrations. However, more smartphone manufacturers seem to be catching on to the need for tighter integration with vehicles.
This feature made its debut on the 2012 CR-V. The 2013 CR-V is priced at $22,695 to $30,195.

title: Active Grille Shutters
subTitle: These will make a car more aerodynamic
promoTeaserSmall: Automakers have found a new tool in the quest for better fuel economy, and it’s not what you might expect.
promoTeaser: Automakers have found a new tool in the quest for better fuel economy, and it’s not what you might expect.
metaTitle: Active Grille Shutters - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Active Grille Shutters: Learn more about how Ford and Dodge have implemented Active Grille Shutters into their newest vehicles to help improve fuel economy.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Automakers have found a new tool in the never-ending quest for better fuel economy, and it's not what you might expect. Without replacing our beloved powerful engines for more sedate options or hacking hundreds of pounds off the car's frame, Ford and Dodge have introduced a new technology that can improve fuel economy by around ten percent, according to Ford.

Debuted in the 2012 Ford Focus, active grille shutters are a small change that can make a significant difference. The shutters are a guillotine-like design that live behind the front grille and slide shut automatically at cruising speeds to help air glide over the hood of the car. This improves aerodynamics, which in turn improves gas mileage, without making any visible changes to the car. The shutters automatically open to allow air to flow when the engine needs to be cooled, usually during low-speed, stop and go traffic.

The grille shutters made their first appearance in the Ford Focus, and have since spread to the Taurus and Escape EcoBoost. Ford plans to continue rolling out the active grille across its lineup. Dodge has also started offering the technology in its Dart and Ram models.

title: It's the Year of the Compact Crossover
promoTitle: It's the Year of the Compact Crossover
promoTeaserSmall: Women have embraced compact crossovers like the Ford Escape and Honda CR-V because they are flexible, fuel efficient, and the right size for most needs.
promoTeaser: Women have embraced compact crossovers like the Ford Escape and Honda CR-V because they are flexible, fuel efficient, and the right size for most needs.
metaTitle: It's the Year of the Compact Crossover - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: It's the Year of the Compact Crossover Learn more about the newest compact crossovers to hit the market for 2013 and beyond. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Women have embraced compact crossovers like the Ford Escape and the Honda CR-V because they are flexible, fuel efficient, and the right size for most needs.

In fact, it wouldn't be too much of a stretch to say that this is the Year of the Compact Crossover, with lots of new and improved models, including the all-new 2013 Ford Escape and Mazda CX-5 and the redesigned CR-V. With gas prices climbing steadily, the fuel-efficient little performers are bound to grow in popularity.

The Escape tops out at 33 mpg on the highway with its 1.6-liter EcoBoost engine mated to a six-speed automatic transmission. It has the distinction already of being the top-selling "utility vehicle" in the United States, and the new model should win even more fans.

J.D. Power and Associates notes that women have made the compact crossover their favored body style. Honda CR-V buyers, in particular, are mainly female. The same is true for such vehicles as the Hyundai Tucson, the Volkswagen Tiguan, and the Kia Sportage.

The CR-V is also worth a look because it has been the bestselling car-based compact utility vehicle in nine of the past fifteen years. The fourth-generation model went on a major diet, losing about 50 pounds and shrinking about an inch in length. The CR-V's lighter weight and better aerodynamics improve fuel efficiency, and that's a big priority in this class. The EPA said the front-wheel-drive 2012 CR-V returned 23 mpg in city driving and 31 mpg on the highway.

Another all-new crossover that's sure to be a style leader is the 2013 Mazda CX-5. Mazda notes that, thanks to its 2.0-liter engine that makes 155 horsepower, you can get up to 26 mpg in town and 35 mpg on the highway--if you opt for the manual transmission. The automatic tops out at 32 mpg on the highway.

Anyone who's ever struggled with groceries and a baby on her hip will appreciate the Escape's hands-free power liftgate, an option on the 2013 model--you just have to kick your foot under the bumper, and up it goes. 

Another clever feature is the seat folding aid in the CR-V. Now you can avoid having to fold up the seat cushions manually before folding down the seat backs. Both operations can be done by simply pulling a lever in the cargo compartment.
You'd be hard pressed to think of another vehicle type that is more friendly for women. You might call it a multi-tasker's best friend.

title: 2013 Volvo XC90
subTitle: Ready for a rapid weight-loss program, spa makeover, and dietary supplements, the XC90 instead endures with only minor changes.
promoTeaserSmall: Ready for a rapid weight-loss program, spa makeover, and dietary supplements, the XC90 instead endures with only minor changes.
promoTeaser: Ready for a rapid weight-loss program, spa makeover, and dietary supplements, the XC90 instead endures with only minor changes.
metaTitle: 2013 Volvo XC90 Buyer's Guide - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Volvo XC90 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: To those who call for the Volvo XC90 to freshen up: you’re right! Once the bestselling SUV from Europe, the XC90 has fallen way behind the curve, and the piddling updates for 2013 will hardly mitigate this laxity. If an important Volvo nameplate has suffered as the result of changes in Volvo’s corporate status, it’s the XC90. It’s the story of how a good-looking face can become merely familiar. The XC90 originated the trim, urbane look in the full-size crossover segment, but nothing has been done with that in years. And problems accelerated, so to speak, when the excellent V-8 departed the engine bay. Now left with the 236 horsepower 3.2-liter six-cylinder and six-speed automatic transmission as the only powertrain, the XC90 is dated and finds itself at a significant disadvantage to competitors; meager power output combines with mediocre fuel economy. For 2013, there are a few new items: for example, a leather strap on the tailgate, red wood trim in the interior, and white lighting for the instrumentation. The list of safety features looked good a few years ago, but today the XC90 even lags behind other Volvos in this aspect. The most important new feature it can receive is a refresh button.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Acura MDX
2. Buick Enclave
3. GMC Acadia

Cool Tech Items:
1. The available active Xenon headlamps are motorized, turning up to 15 degrees in either direction to expand your vision.
2. Blind spot warning system is one of few contemporary driver aids available.
3. Side curtain airbag stays inflated in multiple or long-duration accidents whether windows are up or down.

Looks:
1. Choose from a selection of seventeen- to twenty-inch alloy wheels.
2. Color-coordinated fender extensions add some “bad” to the XC90.
3. A plethora of cargo and towing options are available.

New for 2013:
1. Standard rain-sensing windshield wipers and headlamp washers.
2. LED daytime running lamps and tail lamps are added.
3. Red wood interior trim (steering wheel, shift knob, inlays) adorn the interior.

title: The Car Seat Whisperers
subTitle: What You Need to Know Now
promoTeaserSmall: Car seats are essential —but you’ve got to get the right size and install it correctly. There are people out there who will help. Go see them.
promoTeaser: Car seats are essential —but you’ve got to get the right size and install it correctly. There are people out there who will help. Go see them.
metaTitle: Car Seat Safety from JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: At a community event, parents get expert help from volunteers and pros to get their children's car seat installed the best way for safety. With video.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

relatedArticles.name: article0
relatedArticles.promoTeaser: Yes, your eight-year-old still needs a car seat. Time to play the Because I Said So card.
relatedArticles.title: What Car Seat When?

pageElements.text: If you’re a parent, you probably remember the strange sensation you have when you’re allowed to take your child home for the first time. There’s that little voice in your head saying, Really? You are letting me take this person home? Can I be trusted?
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/S3R6dg38V-8?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

It’s good to know that on one issue, at least—your child’s car seat—there actually is a village to help you. Both the Safe Kids organization and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) run events around the country to help you install your child seat absolutely correctly. The trained experts you’ll find there come armed with the latest rules and information, not only about installation but about what kind of seat a child should have at different sizes and ages.

Jean Knows Cars paid a visit to a car seat event at our local fire station in mid-September. As a veteran car seat user, I thought I knew everything about car seats. Not so! I learned that volunteer and paid car seat checkers attend an intensive thirty-two-hour course to learn how to do it right, and then they share this knowledge with the community at free events.  You can make an appointment, drive in, and have a team of experts get into your vehicle and show you how it’s done. And you should.

Our local Safe Kids effort, affiliated with the University of Michigan’s Mott Children’s Hospital, has a Buckle Up hotline that parents can call to have a car seat check while they are still at the hospital delivering their baby. Or they can get the check taken care of ahead of time. As you’ll see in the accompanying video, we met a woman being proactive and having the check while still in her third trimester of pregnancy. Another woman came with her active toddler and cheerful 18-month-old to get a pair of new seats installed.
