The technicians educated her that rear facing is still safest at least until age two, then off they all went, with both boys happily settling in to their new seats.

It was great to learn that low-income families who qualify can get new, safe child seats free of charge. In Michigan, the money to do this comes from a grant from the state’s Office of Highway Safety Planning.

So go ahead, doubt your parenting abilities in 100 different areas—I know I have! But go get a car seat check in your own neighborhood so you can drive off, secure in the knowledge that you’re doing that part right.
Find an event at:
www.nhtsa.gov/cps/cpsfitting/index.cfm
www.safekids.org/in-your-area/find-a-inspection-station/

title: 2013 Dodge Avenger
subTitle: America’s cheapest mid-sized sedan isn’t as boring as it looks. Just don’t ask it to avenge anything.
promoTeaserSmall: America’s cheapest mid-sized sedan isn’t as boring as it looks. Just don’t ask it to avenge anything.
promoTeaser: America’s cheapest mid-sized sedan isn’t as boring as it looks. Just don’t ask it to avenge anything.
metaTitle: 2013 Dodge Avenger - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Dodge Avenger here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: America loves its mid-size sedans. But poor Dodge wouldn’t know about that; it hasn’t been a player in that segment for decades. When its current offering, the Avenger, came along in 2008, adopting the window treatment and muscular rear fenders of the big Charger sedan, customers ran in horror once they drove it—that is, if they could get past the wretched interior. Dodge gave the Avenger a thorough make-over for 2011, although no one seemed to notice, since the bulk of the work was done in places no one could see. The car’s sloppy handling was cleaned up, and a fabulous new 283-horsepower V-6 engine was offered. With its standard six-speed automatic transmission, V-6-powered Avengers achieve decent fuel economy (29 mpg highway). A four-cylinder model is offered, too, although with its antiquated four-speed automatic, highway mileage is not a lot better (31 mpg). The interior was simply revolutionized, with soft-touch material everywhere, edgy new color schemes, and handy connectivity features. In the end, the Avenger became a decent car overall. However, that was 2011, and nothing about the Avenger has changed much since then…except, that is, its competitive set, which now includes fresher (and better) mid-sizers from pretty much every carmaker that offers one. The Avenger’s sole claim to fame for 2013 is its status as the cheapest entry in the segment, as it should be. Its replacement is expected by 2014, which can’t come soon enough for Dodge.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Honda Accord
2. Chevrolet Malibu
3. Ford Fusion

Cool Tech:
1. LED taillamps standard on all models.
2. Uconnect infotainment system with forty-gigabyte hard drive, 6.5-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth, USB.
3. Sirius Travel Link with real-time traffic updates.

Looks:
1. Eighteen-inch aluminum wheels, sporty exterior trim, black/red interior on SXT Rallye Appearance package.
2. Available leather.
3. Eighteen-inch polished wheels, hood stripes, menacing styling, distinct interior on R/T.

New for 2013:
1. Billet Silver, Crystal Blue, and True Blue Pearl added to palette.
2. Enhanced Rallye Appearance package.

title: 2013 Cadillac ATS
subTitle: This all-new sport sedan is Cadillac’s hope for a rear-wheel-drive car that lines up with the best the Germans have to offer.
metaTitle: 2013 Cadillac ATS Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Cadillac ATS here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The ATS is an important car for Cadillac—as you probably realize if you saw any of the elaborate series of adventure-driving commercials featuring the ATS on TV this summer. Cadillac is promoting this car in grand style, aiming it at people who would otherwise be looking at German performance cars. In fact, Cadillac has had BMW’s 3-series and other German sport sedans in its sights for years. With the ATS, which it tested at Germany’s Nürburgring racetrack, among other places, it may have hit the target. What’s most interesting about the ATS? It weighs less than 3,400 pounds, pretty slim for its size. It is a traditional rear-wheel-drive sport sedan, but all-wheel drive is also available. Cadillac makes much of the car’s fifty-fifty weight balance, ultra-efficient and driver-adjustable sport suspension, Brembo brakes, and long, sleek body on a 109.3-inch wheelbase. But what you’ll notice even before you take off are the interior elements. There’s carbon fiber, wood, and metal plate trim; a wraparound instrument panel with LED lighting on the gauges; and a full palette of color schemes. You can dress it up with Bose stereo, navigation, the Cadillac User Experience information and entertainment system with eight-inch touchscreen, and performance seats with power-adjustable bolsters. Safety options are the complete package, too: intelligent brake assist, forward collision alert, lane departure warning, a rear-vision camera, and side blind zone alert, among others. But what Cadillac wants you to take most to heart is a thrilling driving experience from the 272-horsepower four-cylinder turbo engine.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. BMW 3-Series
2. Mercedes-Benz C250
3. Audi A4

Cool Tech:
1. Cadillac User Experience information/entertainment system, making its debut on the XTS and ATS this year.
2. Front and rear automatic brakes use short-range radar technology and ultrasonic sensors to prevent low-speed collisions.
3. Five-link independent rear suspension, a first for Cadillac.

Looks:
1. They call it Art & Science design language; we call it ruggedly handsome, even sexy.

title: 2013 Acura TSX
subTitle: Acura’s sporty sedan comes with seemingly endless choices
metaTitle: 2013 Acura TSX Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Acura TSX Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The 2013 Acura TSX makes no changes from the 2012 model year, but it comes with enough options to make up for it. The TSX comes as a sedan or wagon, with either a 2.4-liter 201-horsepower engine (lots of fun, even if it lacks some power) or a 3.5-liter V-6 with more brute force. Acura’s silky-smooth manual transmission is available in the sedan. The TSX compliments its punchy engine with a new, smoother suspension. The sedan has a paltry 12.6 cubic feet of trunk storage, but this car was clearly not built to move a family cross-country, and with its other features you might not miss the space. If you do need more room in the back, the wagon has twice the cargo space of the sedan. Believe it or not, a car this fun to drive doesn’t have to be a gas guzzler. At 19 to 22 mpg in the city and 28 to 31 mpg on the highway, the TSX is more efficient than Acura’s more sedate (read: boring) sedans. Its relatively low cost is reflected in the lack of a navigation system in the manual, and the more powerful V-6 comes at a premium. These small sacrifices just might be worth it for the chance to drive the TSX.
Fun-O-Meter:7

Competitors:
1. Audi A4
2. BMW 328i
3. Infiniti G25

Cool Tech:
1. Achieves up to 30 mpg highway.
2. USB and auxiliary audio jacks.
3. Hands-free phone interface.

Looks:
1. Comes in attention-grabbing Milano Red.
2. Two different body styles: sedan and wagon.

title: 2013 GMC Acadia
subTitle: An already good-looking crossover gets better, inside and out
metaTitle: 2013 GMC Acadia Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 GMC Acadia here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The GMC Acadia is one of GM’s trio of full-size crossovers that also includes the Chevy Traverse and Buick Enclave. Being a plus-sized model in the crossover utility class has its advantages, chief among them being how eight passengers can fit inside more comfortably than in some minivans (a seven-seat configuration is optional, with second-row captains chairs and a center console). The standard Acadia is available in four trim levels as well as a blingy Denali grade, the latter bringing more shiny surfaces than a disco ball and a considerably upgraded interior with a gorgeous, brown leather upholstery option. Cargo room is the best thing this side of a minivan: the Acadia can accommodate a four-foot-wide sheet of plywood inside. Every Acadia is powered by a 3.6-liter V-6 with 288 horsepower paired to a six-speed automatic transmission; an “intelligent” all-wheel-drive system is the only powertrain-related option. It’s hardly fast, but it can get out of its own way just fine. Speaking of getting out of the way, the Acadia (along with the other members of GM’s crossover trio) comes with the industry’s first front center air bag, which deploys between the front seats to prevent occupants’ heads from hitting each other in a side collision or rollover, yet another reason to like a vehicle wherein there is a lot to like already.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Ford Explorer
2. Honda Pilot
3. Dodge Durango

Cool Tech items
1. Innovative front center airbag.
2. Side blind zone alert and rear cross traffic alert systems.

Looks
1. Diffused LED running lamps and new LED taillamp design.
2. Eight-passenger seating, seven-passenger available with second-row captains chairs.
3. Heaps of extra chrome, twenty-inch wheels, upgraded interior fitments on Denali model.

New for 2013
1. Freshened exterior styling.
2. Refined interior.
3. OnStar, Pandora, Gracenote, etc. now integrated into infotainment system.

title: 2013 GMC Savana
subTitle: Whether you carry people or boxes, GMC’s big Savana van can hold lots of ‘em. But not as well as its competition.
metaTitle: 2013 GMC Savana Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 GMC Savana here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Chances are, if you are reading this entry, you’re not interested in the subtle nuances of the Savana’s steering feel, its styling influences, or the material composition of its lower control arms. You either care about how many seatbelts it has (up to fifteen), or how much junk you can cram in the back (a lot). Or both. And that’s cool. Full-size vans are generally little more than big, graceless transportation appliances designed not for the driver, but rather for what’s behind him or her. So who’s going to notice—or care, really—that the Savana hasn’t changed much for the last sixteen years? Probably no one, unless they know that Ford just launched its all-new, full-sized 2013 Transit van, that Nissan sells a big box called NV, or that Ram is rumored to be launching a replacement for the Dodge Sprinter, which, by the way, is still sold here by Mercedes-Benz. Compared with all of those, the Savana feels decidedly old-school, and less roomy. And while it offers a slew of engines ranging from a puny V-6 to an E85-capable gasoline V-8 to a torque-laden 6.6-liter diesel V-8, and has added park assist, a rear camera, and navigation-assisted radio options, the Savana is unremarkable and outdated.
Fun-O-Meter: 1

Competitors:
1. Nissan NV
2. Ford Transit Connect
3. Mercedes-Benz Sprinter

Cool Tech items
1. Ummm…..

Looks
1. Old-school styling.
2. Way less spacious than competition.
3. One man’s panel van is another man’s blank canvas.

New for 2013
1. Available park assist.
2. Available rear vision camera.
3. Available navigation radio.

title: 2013 GMC Terrain
subTitle: Terrain: a square-jawed, better-dressed version of the Chevrolet Equinox
metaTitle: 2013 GMC Terrain Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 GMC Terrain here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: GMC presents itself as an upscale alternative to Chevrolet, and in no instance is this truer than with the Terrain, GMC’s mid-sized, five-passenger and identical twin to the Chevy Equinox. No bad thing, though, as both vehicles are quite nice overall. The Terrain’s rectilinear styling inside and out attempt to cast a more technical, masculine impression, though it can be seen by some as a bit over the top (particularly that obnoxious grille). The level of feature content is high, however, and fit and finish—a strong suit of GM’s of late—are excellent. Close your eyes (as a passenger, of course) and the smooth ride and quiet cabin may fool you into thinking you’re in a Lexus RX350, particularly in the case of the new-for-2013 Denali model, with its upgraded front shocks. The Denali also features an even glitzier grille, unique wheels, smoked mahogany trim, French seams, and a soft-touch dashboard. But you don’t have to spend Denali money to enjoy the Terrain’s huge, sliding back seat, excellent ergonomics, and complimentary six months of OnStar services. Power brokers may prefer the newly available 301-horsepower V-6, while efficiency-minded customers may gravitate to the 182-horsepower four-cylinder engine that features a transmission with “eco” mode. Even with optional all-wheel drive, the Terrain breaks little ground (pardon the pun) in the market, but it straddles the line between the mainstream and luxury ends of the mid-size SUV crossover class, and as such, is reasonably priced.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Ford Edge
2. Toyota Venza
3. Acura RDX

Cool Tech items
1. Side blind zone alert and rear cross traffic alert systems.
2. New Safety package with collision alert, lane departure warning, park assist.
3. IntelliLink infotainment system with integrated OnStar, Pandora, Gracenote, etc.

Looks
1. Wheels ranging from seventeen to nineteen inches.
2. Softer leather, smoked mahogany wood trim in Denali.
3. Standard ambient lighting.

New for 2013
1. Range-topping Denali model.
2. 301-horsepower 3.6-liter V-6 replaces optional 3.0-liter V-6.
3. Altantis Blue, Champagne Silver, Ashen Grey, Iridium exterior colors.

title: 2013 Land Rover LR2
subTitle: The 2013 Land Rover LR2 gets a smaller engine and a bigger sticker price.
metaTitle: 2013 Land Rover LR2  Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Land Rover LR2 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Poor fuel economy was one of the big concerns about the outgoing Land Rover LR2, which returned just 15 mpg city. But big changes are on tap for the new model year as the 2013 LR2 gets a smaller engine with an eye toward improved fuel economy. The baby Land Rover gets a new 240-horsepower turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine replacing the previous 3.2-liter inline six-cylinder engine. The new engine is borrowed from the 2012 Range Rover Evoque and is 88 pounds lighter than the outgoing inline six-cylinder engine it replaces. The engine is linked to a six-speed automatic transmission. The EPA has yet to provide the most critical information about the redesign – namely, the fuel economy, but the numbers are expected to be significantly better. In the meantime, buyers should be prepared to shell out more for the 2013 model, since the base crossover gets a $700 price increase. The 2013 Land Rover LR2 starts at $37,250, which is still cheaper than the BMW X3, one of its chief rivals. The LR2 gets a mini- makeover said to give it a sportier look. The LR2’s cabin also borrows items from the Evoque, including a new center console. Off-roaders will appreciate the fact that, despite the overhaul, the LR2 retains the same 8.3-inch minimum of ground clearance to play hard on rocky, sandy, rutted, or muddy terrain.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. BMW X3
2. Audi Q5
3. Infiniti EX37
4. Mercedes-Benz GLK

Cool Tech:
1. Up-level HSE model is equipped with a rearview camera with “hitch assist,” a graphic superimposed on the camera showing the position of the tow ball, a must for anybody hauling a boat or trailer.

New for 2013:
1. New 240-horsepower turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine.
2. New exterior look.
3. New lighting, front and rear.
4. Three new exterior colors: Aintree Green, Havana and Mauritius Blue.
5. New center console with a seven-inch color touchscreen.
6. Original Terrain Response dial replaced by buttons.

title: 2013 Land Rover Range Rover Evoque
subTitle: The 2013 Range Rover Evoque marks a major shift for the British brand.
metaTitle: 2013 Land Rover Range Rover Evoque Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Land Rover Range Rover Evoque here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Land Rover Range Rover Evoque is a carryover model, since the stylish SUV was just introduced in 2012. It comes with either two or four doors and is the only two-door in the lineup – and the smallest model the automaker has ever built. The Evoque won major accolades, including being named the 2012 North American Truck of the Year by a prestigious panel of auto journalists. The Evoque marked a major shift for the British brand, which had been known for its boxy SUVs designed to tackle the harshest environment. The Evoque is showing the brand’s softer side. Victoria Beckham, the fashion designer and former Spice Girl, even created an Evoque Special Edition last spring, complete with a matching set of luggage, but the special model has yet to debut on the U.S. market. In the meantime, buyers will be attracted to the original’s appealing design, premium interior, and surprisingly roomy cabin. There is a downside to the sleek styling, however. The narrow windows may limit visibility and the cargo area is not as roomy as you’d expect from a Land Rover. The Evoque is powered by a respectable 240-horsepower 2.0-liter turbocharged inline four-cylinder engine – the vehicle’s sole powerplant. The engine is linked to a six-speed automatic transmission. Fuel economy is so-so at 20 mpg in city driving and 28 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. And just like a designer outfit, the Evoque comes with a high starting price.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Audi Q5
2. BMW X3
3. Mercedes-Benz GLK-Class
4. Volvo XC60

Cool tech:
1. MagneRide suspension continually adjusts to provide a smooth and controlled ride on any road surface.

Looks:
1. Contrast roof color.
2. New wheel finish on Prestige model.

New for 2013:
1. Five-door model.
2. Park assist feature.
3. Off-road navigation for vehicles with navigation systems.

title: 2013 Land Rover Range Rover Sport
subTitle: The 2013 Range Rover Sport can go off-roading but prefers the pavement.
metaTitle: 2013 Land Rover Range Rover Sport Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Land Rover Range Rover Sport here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: You may feel like the Duchess of Cambridge in the 2013 Range Rover Sport, one of the most compelling vehicles in the Land Rover lineup. Like Kate Middleton, who can throw an inexpensive sweater over a designer gown and look great, the Range Rover Sport, with its understated British elegance, provides an ideal blend of performance, style, capability, and value. It slots in between the Range Rover Evoque and the full-size Range Rover and gets lots of kudos for its modern interior, great acceleration, and handling, along with its excellent driving position that provides a commanding view of the road. You may need access to the Queen’s treasury, though, when it comes to the gas pump. At its worst, the 2013 Range Rover Sport returns just 12 mpg in city driving and 17 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. The Range Rover Sport is equipped with either a 375-horsepower 5.0-liter V-8 engine or a supercharged 510-horsepower V-8 engine linked to a six-speed automatic transmission. It features standard full-time all-wheel drive and a Terrain Response system. Some buyers may object to the firm ride, but the Range Rover Sport should be on your shopping list if you need something to take you from the trail to the country club with ease. However, it’s not cheap, ranging in price from around $60,000 to $86,000.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. BMW X5
2. Mercedes-Benz M-Class
3. Jeep Grand Cherokee SRT8
4. Porsche Cayenne

Cool Tech:
1. A “say what you see” intuitive voice control for navigation and infotainment.

New for 2013:
1. New Supercharged Limited Edition and GT Limited Edition.
2. Newly optional towing package.

title: 2013 Mazda 3
subTitle: The 2013 Mazda 3 is sporty, but polarizing.
metaTitle: 2013 Mazda 3 Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Mazda 3 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Mazda 3 is one of our favorite compact cars, with sporty handling and a wider availability of the efficient Skyactiv drivetrain technology on tap for the new model year. But despite a recent makeover that toned down the Mazda 3’s goofy grille, the styling can be polarizing. On the plus side, some models – the Mazda 3 comes in sedan or hatchback form– get up to 40 mpg on the highway. If you want to save at the pump, check out the 155-horsepower Skyactiv-G 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine. But you’re going to find a bit of a trade-off since the Mazda 3 is relatively expensive. While the base 2013 Mazda 3 starts at just under $16,000, including a $795 destination charge, the top-of-the-line model is priced at $23,695, including shipping. The Mazda 3 is meant for people who don’t think of their car as an appliance and want a sportier look and feel. The compact Mazda doesn’t disappoint in this area, offering five- or six-speed manual transmissions, in addition to a five- or six-speed automatic transmission. The handling is more performance-oriented than you usually find in this class. The interior has good quality materials and there are upscale options, such as a blind spot monitoring system, something that you usually see on luxury cars.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Ford Focus
2. Honda Civic
3. Hyundai Elantra
4. Nissan Versa
5. Toyota Corolla

Cool Tech:
1. Blind spot monitoring system is optional and usually found on more expensive vehicles.

New for 2013:
1. Air conditioning is now standard.
2. Skyactiv 2.0-liter four-cylinder now comes on the i Sport sedan in addition to two other Mazda 3s.
3. USB port and a driver-information system.

title: 2013 Mazda 5
subTitle: The 2013 Mazda 5 is a stealth minivan.
metaTitle: 2013 Mazda 5 Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Mazda 5 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: If a minivan is the automotive equivalent of mommy jeans, then the 2013 Mazda 5 is more like a pair of skinny jeans. The Mazda 5 is a small minivan with the classic minivan sliding side doors. Yet it has managed to avoid the dreaded minivan stigma. It was redesigned in 2012 and is so stylish that it won’t even matter if you carry a diaper bag in your daily life. The Mazda 5 is a surprisingly versatile vehicle that can seat up to six people in three rows. On the safety side, all passengers – even those in the rear – are protected by side curtain air bags. On the plus side, the little Japanese minivan offers nimble handling, excellent steering feel, good visibility, and a configurable interior. The second-row captain’s chairs slide, recline, and fold flat, and the third-row seats have a fifty-fifty split so they can be tipped forward to create a flat loading area. It should be noted here that there is limited cargo room in the rear with the seats up. A 157-horsepower 2.5 liter four-cylinder engine is the sole engine available. It is linked to a six-speed manual transmission or a five-speed automatic transmission. Fuel economy is so-so at 21 mpg in city driving and 28 mpg on the highway with either transmission, according to the EPA. That’s just a little better than the bigger Chrysler Town & Country minivan, which returns 17 mpg in city driving and 25 mpg on the highway and offers a lot more room.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Nissan Cube
2. Scion xD
3. Toyota Matrix

New for 2013:
1. New USB port.
2. Map pocket added to driver’s side.
3. Restyled seat upholstery.

title: 2013 Acura ZDX
subTitle: The ZDX resists categorization, but that’s not always a bad thing.
metaTitle: 2013 Acura ZDX Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Acura ZDX Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The 2013 ZDX continues that model’s tradition as the odd cousin of the Acura brand. It looks like a coupe, but it has the Acura MDX’s much larger platform and 300-horsepower V-6 engine. It has more cargo space than a sedan, but less than most crossovers. And if you’re tall, you may find the high floor and low ceiling confining. That said, the ZDX doesn’t disappoint on power or handling. It comes with Acura’s supremely effective all-wheel-drive system and can keep the car under control even with a sprightly driver behind the wheel. The ZDX has distinctive exterior styling that makes it a controversial entry into Acura’s brand, but it is certainly more interesting and sporty than some other crossovers. New for 2013 are an optional technology package with leather seats, keyless entry and push-button start, and a fancy new navigation system with real-time traffic rerouting that could shave seconds off your commute. Even if you don’t feel like shelling out for the extras, a base model includes a leather dash and a convenient USB jack and auxiliary audio input for direct connectivity to an iPod or other device.

Fun-O-Meter:
7

Competitors:
1. BMW X6
2. Infiniti FX
3. Volvo XC60

Cool Tech:
1. New navigation system with traffic re-routing.
2. USB and auxiliary input jacks.

Looks:
1. Leather dash and steering wheel, available leather seats.
2. LED backlighting throughout.

New for 2013:
1. Available technology package.
2. Exterior redesign.

title: 2013 Aston Martin DB9
subTitle: A British icon that oozes the sex appeal of David Beckham, the cool of Mick Jagger, and the edginess of Bono.
metaTitle: 2013 Aston Martin DB9 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Aston Martin DB9 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: If you want to turn heads, drive an Aston Martin DB9. The DB9 has an unforgettable figure that causes pedestrians everywhere to do a double take. Drivers of less full-figured cars will gape in envy. When it comes to beauty, no one holds a candle to Aston Martin.  The sleek curves belie the fact that the DB9 is outfitted with a powerful engine – a V12 that makes 470 horsepower, so you’ll also be driving wickedly fast, while maintaining a sporty, cosmopolitan profile.

The DB9 has smart handling features. You’ll notice that when you are playing with the Touchtronic 2 six-speed paddle shifters, which propel the DB9 from 0 to 60 mph in 4.6 seconds. The gears crank into action with a push of a button moving through park, neutral, and drive to reverse. The DB9 doesn't provide the satisfying engine growl found in some other exotic sports cars, but its looks and respectable performance are enough to earn it high marks from critics. Finally, the resplendent woods and leathers on the inside make for a fancy environment, best experienced in the front seats.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors
1. Jaguar XK
2. Lamborghini Gallardo
3. Bentley GT

Cool Tech items
1. You’ll feel grand when you push buttons at the top of the center console to switch gears.
2. The optional Bang & Olufsen sound system in the DB9 Volante.
3. Adaptive damping system allows you to adjust the suspension settings.

Looks
1. A divine piece of sculptural sheetmetal.
2. The high gloss of aluminum makes the car appear to be a piece of jewelry.
3. The stiff structure of the Volante convertible counterpart cuts a neat profile.

title: 2013 Aston Martin DBS
subTitle: The DBS is another beauty pageant winner for Aston Martin, but a more thorough examination reveals a classic on life support.
metaTitle: 2013 Aston Martin DBS Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Aston Martin DBS Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: If you’re driving a DBS, you’ve earned bragging rights. The DBS is the distinguished flagship that represents the best of Aston Martin – at least it was when it first came out in 2008 and replaced the Vanquish. But now the DBS is being phased out by the Vanquish. The DBS cast the mold that both the Aston Martin DB9 and the Virage have followed and polished to pristine perfection. You’ll notice that the DBS has more nuanced looks. But is sheet metal botox worth the additional $70,000 price tag? You be the judge. If you pose this question in Hollywood and certain blocks on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, the answer is a resounding yes, so you’re answer is predicated on perspective. The DBS can be ordered as a two-door coupe or in convertible form as the Volante. It qualifies as both fast and foxy, reaching from 0 to 60 mph in 4.3 seconds and topping out at 190 mph. DBS went out with a high-gloss bang, releasing The Carbon Edition model for 2012, which features ten-spoke, gloss-black wheels and a Matrix-style carbon fiber cabin that is sold in flame orange, ceramic gray, and carbon black metallic.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. Ferrari 458
2. Lamborghini Gallardo
3. Jaguar XJ

Cool Tech items
1. For symphonic sound, the Bang & Olufsen sound system is standard.
2. When the convertible top is dropped, the audio adjusts to tune to the wind speed for maximum audible decadence.
3. Carbon fiber brake rotors and body panels give the DBS a performance edge.

Looks
1. A sunken front spoiler.
2. Wheels that are set like stones on a diamond ring.

New for 2013
1. It’s noteworthy that DBS is relinquishing its flagship title to the AM 310 Vanquish.

title: 2013 Aston Martin Rapide
subTitle: Four doors of decadent fantasy driving in drop-dead gorgeous couture.
metaTitle: 2013 Aston Martin Rapide Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Aston Martin Rapide Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Rapide is the only Aston Martin in which double dates are possible. Two couples can go out to dinner in chic style. Of course, the couple in the backseat should be of the petite variety, because the legroom in the Rapide is minimal. But what’s on the inside of the cabin is gorgeous – embodied in the sculptural shape of the Rapide’s gauges. The Rapide Luxe adds even more stylish pizzazz with a six-piece luggage set, ventilated seats, glass switchgear, and a rear entertainment system. The Rapide is a leaner interpretation of a four-door super car, especially when pitted against the brawny Porsche Panamera. It’s a four-seater that has retained its elegance. DB9 DNA is carried over in the 6.0-liter V-12 engine that produces 470 horsepower and climbs from 0 to 60 mph in 5 seconds. It also has a top speed of 183 mph. In this car, your petite friends can ride in style, while you can enjoy being seen behind the wheel of an Aston Martin.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. Porsche Panamera Turbo S
2. Ferrari FF

Cool Tech items:
1. Dual-screen rear entertainment system in the Luxury model has two 6.5-inch LCD screens.
2. Ventilated front and rear seats.
3. Standard Bang & Olufsen sound system.

Looks
1. The Rapide Luxe has glass switchgears and a six-piece luggage set available in a variety of colors.
2. The gauges, like much of the Rapide's cabin, are works of art.
3. The logo can be embroidered onto the headrest to match the color of the steering wheel and interior.

title: 2013 Aston Martin Vantage
subTitle: The Vantage speaks in the discerning dialect of great British sports cars.
metaTitle: 2013 Aston Martin Vantage Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Aston Martin Vantage Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Vantage is the Topshop of the Aston Martin lineup – very Kensington meets Kate Moss. In the gold plated garage of super cars, the Vantage is nothing to sneeze at. In fact, it somehow manages to come off as more posh than some of its older, pricier, and overloaded siblings. It’s more petite than a DBS, and therefore spunkier. Driving the Vantage is all fun and games with the ability to go 0 to 60 mph in 4.7 seconds. If you bump up to the powerful 510-horsepower V-12 Vantage, you’ll have to brush up on your standard driving skills, whereas the V-8 is offered in both a six-speed automated manual and a six-speed manual transmission. The tradeoff for that tomfoolery at the wheel is an interior that fits like a pair of skinny jeans.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. Porsche 911
2. Audi R8 Coupe
3. Chevrolet Corvette ZR-1

Cool Tech items
1. The V-12 Vantage features carbon-fiber body add-ons, carbon-fiber sill plates, a sport suspension, and Alcantara seat inserts.
2. The Vantage has an integrated Apple iPod connector and a USB connector with waveform audio.
3. The sound system is designed to work with Windows Media Player and MP3 audio files.

Looks
1. Full-grain leather interior and optional Alcantara trimmed steering wheel.
2. The V-12 Vantage features carbon-fiber body add-ons.
3. The carbon-fiber bonnet vents aid performance and add a distinct flourish.

title: 2013 Aston Martin Virage
subTitle: An authentic beauty, cut from distinctive Aston Martin cloth.
metaTitle: 2013 Aston Martin Virage Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Aston Martin Virage Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Virage burst onto the scene in 2011, holding down the middle ground in the Aston Martin model lineup. The Virage is clearly related to its older Aston Martin siblings, but it has its own refined exterior styling.  The Virage is the whole package; it will take you to sports car heaven. In the Virage, you’ll find plenty of thoughtful touches including Aston Martin’s staple hand-stitched leather. The engine, a 5.9-liter V-12, has power that’s wedged evenly between the DBS and the DB9. Substantial twenty-inch wheels give the Virage more of a weighty and grounded appearance. Aluminum, carbon fiber, walnut, and Bridge of Weir leather are melded to created a modernist interior. Glass switches and leather-wrapped steering wheel are what makes Aston Martin interiors beautiful. Add to that carbon-disc brakes and a ten-setting adaptive Bilstein suspension. What this translates to is a hot sports car that handles with confidence, class, and style.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Mercedes SLS AMG
2. Lamborghini Gallardo
3. Maserati Gran Turismo Coupe

Cool Tech:
1. Responsive carbon-ceramic brake discs.
2. Ten-setting adaptive Bilstein suspension.
3. Optional 1,000-watt Bang & Olufsen BeoSound audio system.

Looks:
1.Twenty-inch wheels.
2. Aluminum, carbon fiber, walnut, and Bridge of Weir leather interior.
3. Glass switches.
4. Leather-wrapped steering wheel.

title: 2013 Audi A3
subTitle: All the class of Audi in an unlikely wrapping
metaTitle: 2013 Audi A3 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Audi A3 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: A compact wagon was a novel idea when the Audi A3 came on the market, but since then the A3 has found a home with buyers. The hatchback means there is plenty of room in the trunk, but you won’t feel cramped sitting in the back. The A3 has an available all-wheel-drive system that is unique to its class, and the choice of a turbo-diesel engine means that it can make up to 42 mpg on the highway. The diesel engine is only available in a six-speed automatic, but a six-speed manual is available when you give up the efficiency of the diesel for a standard engine. The interior is awash in typical Audi luxury, with leather trim and seating surfaces, as well as Audi’s navigation and Bose sound system. Though the A3 has a history as the best choice for a small wagon, there are more options these days and it may be worth checking out some of the competition. The A3’s design could use an update to keep up with the pack, but Audi’s name and engineering are usually a good recommendation, and this car is not likely to disappoint.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competition:
1. Lexus CT200h
2. Volkswagen Golf

Cool Tech:
1. Diesel engine earns more than 40 mpg on the highway.
2. Bose sound system with auxiliary jack, available Bluetooth connectivity.
3. Stand-out Audi all-wheel drive.

Look:
1. Luxurious, leather-heavy interior.
2. Available in bright colors including Brilliant Red and Scuba Blue Metallic, three available seat colors.

title: 2013 Audi A4
subTitle: Audi’s impressive and refined luxury sport sedan
metaTitle: 2013 Audi A4 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Audi A4 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Audi A4 is Audi’s basic luxury sedan, and it has gained the respect of drivers with its luxurious interior and exciting performance. The A4 family also includes the sporty S4, which is very fast and offers more choices for the interior. The A4 offers a turbo engine; the S4, a supercharged V-6. A choice of front- or four-wheel drive is available on sedan models, and the four-wheel-drive models come with a choice of a manual or automatic transmission. The exterior styling is typical Audi: making a statement without making you cringe. The interior styling won’t leave you flat either, especially not if you spring for one of the enviable technology packages. New for the 2013 model year are more interior choices, such as a flat-bottom steering wheel and various new seating colors and materials. The base price range tops out just shy of $50,000. (The priciest models include an expensive-but-worth-it Bang & Olufsen sound system.) Despite possible sticker shock for first time luxury buyers, the A4 is very reasonably priced compared with competitors, and buyers give up none of the fun of driving a luxury performance automobile.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competition:
1. BMW 3-series
2. Cadillac CTS
3. Lexus IS

Cool Tech:
1. Four-cylinder engine improves fuel economy without sacrificing performance.
2. Available Bang & Olufsen stereo.
3. Rearview camera, navigation with voice control.

Looks:
1. Available with several new interior/exterior color combinations.
2. Contrast stitching available in sport model.

New for 2013:
1. Navigation computer now standard on S4.
2. A4 now has flex-fuel capability.

title: 2013 Audi A5
subTitle: A hard-to-resist performance coupe with more choices than a fast-food menu
metaTitle: 2013 Audi A5 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Audi A5 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: If choices are what you like, the A5 is the car for you. It comes in five models (an A5 coupe and convertible, an S5 coupe and convertible, and the RS5 coupe) and with seemingly endless drivetrain choices. The A5 models come with a 211-horsepower engine and three transmission choices (including an eight-speed transmission), while the S5 operates with a new V-6 engine that is both faster and more fuel-efficient than the previous model’s larger V-6. The A5 family is undoubtedly impressive in terms of performance, but Audi didn’t stop there. The A5 is no slob. The exterior design is eye-catching; we just wish there was a hard top option on the convertible. The interior showcases Audi’s trademark luxury, and new color choices are available in the 2013 model. Better yet, unlike some convertibles whose back seat would barely fit a toddler, the A5 has room for four adults. The fact that Audi is able to do all this and still produce a vehicle that gets above 30 mpg on the highway is a testament to the design and engineering skills that went into the A5.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competition:
1. BMW 3-series
2. Infiniti G37
3. Lexus IS C

Cool Tech:
1. New engine in S5 increases fuel efficiency and power at the same time.
2. Optional Audi side assist alerts driver to obstacles when changing lanes.
3. RS5 coupe has 354-horsepower V-8 engine.

Look:
1. Excellent exterior styling, several interesting color choices.
2. Convertible models available, fabric top designed to reduce noise and wind.
3. New, sleeker and more intuitive controls.

New for 2013:
1. New drivetrain options in S5.
2. Audi navigation system with Google Maps and available Bluetooth connectivity.
3. Standard three-zone climate control.

title: 2013 Nissan 370Z
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan 370Z boosts your street cred, but it may be too hard-edged for some.
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan 370Z Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan 370Z here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Nissan 370Z has built a solid reputation as a serious, yet affordable sports car. The “Z,” which comes in coupe and convertible models, is designed for driving pleasure and doesn’t disappoint with a stiff suspension, powerful brakes and a throaty engine, but the 2013 models will put a bigger dent in your bank account. The top-of-the-line 2013 Nissan Nismo 370Z starts at $43,800, including shipping, reflecting a $1,360 price increase over the outgoing model. The carryover models get several upgrades including a refreshed front fascia with vertical LED daytime running lights – except on the Nismo 370Z – a new eighteen-inch wheel design for the 370Z Coupe and two new colors – Magma Red and Midnight Blue. The 370Z and 370Z Touring get the standard 332-horsepower 3.7 liter V-6 engine and either a six-speed manual transmission with an optional synchronized downshift rev matching system or a seven-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters. The 2013 Nissan Nismo 370Z gets a 350-horsepower 3.7 liter V-6 engine with a six-speed manual transmission. Be prepared for a stiff ride on public roads, a rather noisy engine, and limited rear visibility. But if you’re looking for classic sports car styling and a car that takes fun seriously, the Z is the way to go.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. Audi TT
2. Chevrolet Camaro
3. Ford Mustang
4. Infiniti G37

Cool Tech:
1. Close-ratio six-speed manual with optional SynchroRev Match on 370Z Roadster Touring only.

New for 2013:
Nissan 370Z Coupe and Roadster:
1. Revised front fascia with LED daytime running lights.
2. New Midnight Blue and Magma Red exterior colors.

Nissan Nismo 370Z:
1. New optional Bose package with six speakers.
2. Red Finish caliper color.
3. New Magma Red exterior color.

title: 2013 Audi A6
subTitle: Fresh redesign makes a good thing even better
metaTitle: 2013 Audi A6 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Audi A6 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Though little has been changed for 2013, the A6 received a full redesign for the 2012 model, bringing it up to date with Audi’s fast-improving technology. Technical improvements include a more rearward position for the engine and 60/40-split, all-wheel drive (emphasis on the back wheels) to give it that sports car feel we all crave. The available supercharged V-6 engine is capable of going from 0 to 60 mph in a speedy 5.3 seconds. The A6 has a luscious interior, with sleek lines and nice materials. An available navigation system has a Google Earth interface and can be set up as a mobile hotspot for up to eight devices. There is even a touchpad that can read your handwriting, though writing on the nav system with one eye on the road is probably at least as dangerous as texting while driving. Luckily, the A6 also includes lane departure warning, blind spot warning, and Audi Pre-Sense Plus, which will take various safety measures including autonomous braking and seatbelt tightening in the half-second before a collision. The A6 seems to have few downsides, though the loss of the wagon model from previous years still stings.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competition:
1. BMW 5-series
2. Cadillac CTS
3. Lexus GS

Cool Tech:
1. Audi MMI technology with Google connectivity and a mobile hotspot.
2. Despite impressive power, still manages more than 30 mpg highway.
3. State-of-the-art safety measures including night vision assistant.

Looks:
1. Aggressive – but not ugly – front end design.
2. Good-looking interior.
3. Optional LED headlights.

New for 2013:
1. All-wheel drive added to 2.0T model.
2. Added start/stop feature.

title: 2013 Nissan Altima
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Altima kicks it up a notch in the midsize sedan segment with a major redesign that includes an overhaul in the cabin.
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Altima Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Altima here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Nissan Altima is shaking up its considerable competition in the mid-size sedan segment with new sheetmetal, a revamped cabin, and a revised four-cylinder engine that’s more powerful and efficient. A new grille and projector-style headlights give the Altima a more dramatic face, with LED taillights standard on uplevel models. The Japanese automaker has carried over the 270-horsepower 3.5-liter V-6 engine in the Altima, but has revised the 2.5-liter four-cylinder, increasing output from 175 to 182 horsepower. A redesigned Xtronic continuously variable transmission boosts fuel economy in both engines – to 27 mpg in city driving and 38 mpg on the highway on the four-cylinder, according to the EPA. The Altima’s cabin gets dolled up with a new articulated seat design, available in cloth or leather, as well as a new advanced Drive-Assist Display. The Altima offers good handling and a compliant ride. Nissan expanded the Altima range with seven trim levels for 2013.The four-cylinder models get either sixteen-inch steel wheels or seventeen-inch alloy rims, while the six-cylinder models come with eighteen-inch alloys. Available safety technologies are plentiful and include blind spot warning, lane departure warning, and moving object detection. The Altima’s changes are impressive, but the mid-size sedan wars are heating up, with the debut of a redesigned 2013 Ford Fusion and 2013 Honda Accord.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Ford Fusion
2. Honda Accord
3. Toyota Camry
4. Hyundai Sonata

Cool Tech:
1. Easy Fill Tire Alert honks horn when correct tire pressure is reached.
2. Optional text-messaging assistant (but it doesn’t work with iPhone).

New for 2013:
1. New sheetmetal.
2. Revamped cabin.
3. Revised four-cylinder engine.

title: 2013 Audi A7
subTitle: Really fast, really good-looking, and it has a hatchback!
metaTitle: 2013 Audi A7 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Audi A7 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Audi’s A7 may be the most unconventional car in its lineup, offering a breath of fresh air from the rest of Audi’s bold-but-similar sedans. The A7 stands out from the crowd because it pairs excessive speed with an unexpected hatchback. No need to worry that Audi has somehow created a dowdy car – the hatchback fits with the A7’s sleek lines and does nothing to slow this car down. The 2013 model will have a top speed electronically limited at 130 mph, while a brand new S7 model is limited to 155 mph. That’s fast enough to make you consider running from those flashing red lights.  Audi didn’t skimp on the interior, either. The 2013 A7 will seat five for the first time with a new middle seat in the second row. Audi’s trademark Google Earth map technology is available, as is an excruciatingly pricey Bang & Olufsen stereo. The A7 will save some fuel with new technology that turns the engine off while the car stands at a stop, and seamlessly back on again when you start rolling. With everything the A7 offers it’s hard to imagine wanting anything else. Except maybe a half-off coupon.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competition:
1. BMW 5-series GT
2. Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class
3. Porsche Panamera

Cool Tech:
1. Despite huge power, gets almost 30 mpg highway.
2. Start/stop fuel-saving engine technology.
3. Available Audi MMI Google interface and mobile hotspot.

Looks:
1. Unexpected, but attractive hatchback.
2. S7 has leather seats and steering wheel.
3. Small rear spoiler for increased stability.

New for 2013:
1. Fifth seat in A7.
2. All-new S7 model.

title: 2013 Nissan Armada
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Armada is an old-school SUV designed to appeal to shoppers who need brawny performance and good towing capabilities – and never look twice at prices at the gas pump.
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Armada Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Armada here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Nissan Armada takes it moniker from a famous fleet of Spanish warships and the giant SUV certainly lives up to its name. It offers beefy, all-weather performance, good towing capabilities and a rugged, utilitarian interior. The muscular Armada can tow up to 9,000 pounds and tackle the outdoors, thanks to its truck chassis and low-range four-wheel drive that can handle extreme towing or off-roading needs. A third-row seat is standard and eight passengers can ride comfortably in the spacious Armada. Its standard engine, a 5.6-liter V-8, is rated at 317 horsepower. The engine is linked to a five-speed automatic transmission. But the Armada is thirsty, delivering 12 mpg in city driving and 19 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. The Armada, which has a heavy-duty, fully boxed ladder frame, drives like a truck and can be a beast to maneuver into tight parking spaces. Although the interior on the base model feels somewhat cheap, Nissan continues to offer packages that dress up the cabin. For 2013, a new Platinum Reserve package debuts, adding twenty-inch dark chrome wheels, dark chrome grille, and outside mirrors, along with a two-tone Chocolate/Almond leather-trimmed seating with dark satin chrome interior accents. If $4-a-gallon gas prices don’t bother you, the Armada may be a logical choice.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1.Toyota Sequoia
2. Ford Expedition
3. Chevrolet Tahoe
4. GMC Yukon

New for 2013:
1. New Platinum Reserve package adds twenty-inch dark chrome wheels, dark chrome grille and outside mirrors, Chocolate/Almond leather-trimmed seating, and dark satin chrome interior accents.
2. Dual seven-inch headrest system added to Platinum models, available on SV and SL models.
3. Slide-on-rod sunvisors with mirror and illumination now standard on all models.
4. Bluetooth added as standard on SV models.
5. Five new exterior colors include Midnight Garnet, Graphite Blue, Gun Metallic, Pearl White, and Java Metallic.

title: 2013 Audi A8
subTitle: Audi’s flagship has us coming back for more
metaTitle: 2013 Audi A8 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Audi A8 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The A8 is Audi’s top-of-the line sedan, and it has plenty of features to back up that title. This model year's A8s will be available in four models, including a much-hyped S8 that goes from 0 to 60 mph in a very speedy 3.9 seconds. The A8’s exterior design hasn’t changed substantially, but the previous models are so good they didn’t warrant much tinkering. The A8 has long been one of the most balanced, well-proportioned sedans on the market. It carries Audi’s all-wheel drive, and despite being one of the largest sedans in its class, it maintains decent fuel mileage in some models with a highway range falling just short of 30 mpg. The interior of the A8 is quite swanky, with leather seats, wood and aluminum trim, and available extras like Audi’s MMI Google Earth interface and a rear entertainment system. A full-leather option is also available, just in case you want to spend more money on this already very expensive vehicle. Beautiful interior aside, the A8 is really about superior engineering and unnecessary (but impressive) speed, and in that respect, it absolutely delivers.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competition:
1. BMW 7-series
2. Hyundai Equus
3. Lexus LS

Cool Tech:
1. Available Audi MMI technology with Google Earth and mobile hotspot.
2. New, smaller S8 engine also more powerful and more efficient.

Looks:
1. Proportional, attractive exterior.
2. Very posh interior.
3. Eight available color combinations.

New for 2013:
1. New S8 model.
2. Variable cylinder technology saves fuel.

title: 2013 Audi Allroad
subTitle: The Allroad is back from retirement
metaTitle: 2013 Audi Allroad Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Audi Allroad Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Audi will reintroduce the Allroad for 2013, after excluding it from the lineup for seven years. The Allroad is longer and a little higher off the ground than previous models, which gives it more clearance to better handle varying terrain. Audi does not sacrifice style for performance, and the Allroad is attractive, despite having a very wagon-ish feel. Audi’s trademark grille and headlight styling are prominent in the Allroad, and the interior is much more spacious than Audi’s sedans. New seating allows more headroom for passengers, and there is plenty of storage space for bags or gear.  Audi’s new Connect technology can make use of Google Earth connectivity and turn the car into a roving hotspot. There is an available Bang & Olufsen sound system, though it is almost prohibitively expensive and requires an upgrade to the Prestige trim level. Features that come standard in other Audis need to be purchased for the Allroad, but with its $39,000 base price (one of the lowest in Audi’s fleet) and all the benefit of Audi’s fine engineering the Allroad is still a good car for the money.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competition:
1. Volvo XC70
2. BMW X3
3. Cadillac SRX

Cool Tech:
1. Adaptive cruise control automatically reacts to other cars and road conditions.
2. Audi MMI technology and Bang & Olufsen sound system available.
3. Available Audi side assist for safety.

Looks:
1. Distinctive Audi headlights and grille.
2. Panoramic sunroof.
3. Attractive interior with available wood grain trim.

New for 2013:
1. An all-new reboot.

title: 2013 Nissan Cube
subTitle: The funky 2013 Nissan Cube makes it hip to be square.
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Cube
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Cube here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The boxy 2013 Nissan Cube has a polarizing look that buyers either love or hate. Some say it has styling inspired by a bulldog. Quirky touches include a refrigerator-style rear door and an asymmetrical rear window. Regardless of how you look at it, the Cube is a tall hatchback that is remarkably practical and comfortable with a low step-in height. A well behind the rear seats provides decent cargo space and the seats fold forward, but not flat into the floor. The Cube suffers from sluggish acceleration and unsupportive seats, along with numb power steering. The Cube choices are somewhat limited for the new model year, with Nissan deleting the Cube 1.8 base model, Cube 1.8 S Indigo Limited Edition and the Cube Cargo Version. There are now just two models to choose from: the Cube 1.8 S and Cube 1.8 SL. The front-wheel-drive Cube gets a standard 122-horsepower 1.9-liter four-cylinder engine linked to either a six-speed manual transmission or Xtronic continuously variable transmission. The CVT-equipped model returns 27 mpg in city driving and 31 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. The fun quotient in the Cube can be increased with the addition of more than forty accessories, including a custom grille, an exterior graphics package and interior design kit with a shag dash topper. Austin Powers would love it.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Honda Fit
2. Kia Soul
3. Scion xD

Cool Tech:
1. Interface system for iPod.

New for 2013:
1. Simplified lineup with only two models available.
2. Sapphire Slate is new exterior color.
3. A PUREDRIVE badge, indicating fuel and emissions efficiency is added on all models.

title: 2013 Audi Q5
subTitle: Audi’s first crossover still holds up
metaTitle: 2013 Audi Q5 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cas
metaDescription: 2013 Audi Q5 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: By far the most exciting thing to happen to the Audi Q5 in 2013 is the addition of a hybrid option to the existing models.  The hybrid will increase the Q5’s already strong gas mileage (20 mpg in the city, 28 mpg on the highway) and add yet more options to the versatile crossovers. Last year’s unsatisfactory V-6 engine will be replaced by a supercharged 272-horsepower option. Buyers can also stick with the previously successful four-cylinder engine.  The Q5 also makes use of Audi’s famous quattro all-wheel drive. A quintessential crossover, the Q5’s exterior avoids the boring trappings of a sedan without looking like a hulking SUV. This design has proved effective in the past, with the Q5 boasting Audi’s second-best sales. In addition to changes to engines, the Q5 has had some improvements to the interior. New aluminum trim options make the inside more attractive, while available Audi Connect technology means the Q5 can access the Internet and connect with Google Maps. Audio controls have also been integrated into the steering wheel for greater convenience.  The new Q5 will also sport Audi’s aggressive and unmistakable new grille and headlight design.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competition:
1. Acura RDX
2. BMW X3
3. Lexus RX

Cool Tech:
1. New supercharged powertrain option.
2. Available Audi Connect technology.
3. Standard Sirius XM radio.

Looks:
1. Aggressive-looking headlamps and front grille.
2. Nine exterior color options with four available trim colors.
3. Interior wood trim with brushed aluminum accents.

New for 2013:
1. New hybrid model.
2. Interior upgrades.

title: 2013 Nissan GT-R
subTitle: The Nissan GT-R used to offer supercar performance for a less-than-supercar price, but buyers should be prepared for some major sticker shock on the 2013 model.
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan GT-R
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan GT-R here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Nissan describes the 2013 GT-R as “an incredible value,” but buyers should brace themselves for some major sticker shock this year. The base 2013 Nissan GT-R Premium model starts at $97,820, reflecting a $6,870 increase over the outgoing model. The 2013 Nissan GT-R Black Edition starts at $107,320, reflecting an $11,200 price hike. Still, the GT-R is significantly cheaper than some of its chief competition, most notably the Porsche 911 Turbo. The 2013 GT-R gets performance enhancements, including a boost in horsepower from 530 to 545. It is equipped with a 3.8-liter twin-turbo V-6 engine linked to a six-speed automated manual transmission, but it lacks a conventional stick shift. The GT-R stands out with its distinctive good looks, standard adaptive suspension and four-season potential thanks to all-wheel drive. The suspension on the 2013 model has been retuned and the Black Edition gets a new dry carbon fiber spoiler. The new spoiler is handmade in a limited production run. Six exterior colors are available for 2013, including a four-stage metallic Super Silver. The GT-R scores points for its incredible performance, near-telepathic handling, and nice cabin. But it could be more involving and has a harsh, fidgety ride. Putting the GT-R through its paces on public roads may attract the attention of the local constabulary. To experience its true potential, it must be unleashed on a track.
Fun-O-Meter: 10

Competitors:
1. Audi R8
2. Chevrolet Corvette
3. Porsche 911 Turbo
4. BMW M3

Cool Tech:
1. On-board driving recorder.

New for 2013:
1. Performance enhancements, including a boost in horsepower from 530 to 545.
2. New blue lighting treatment inside the tachometer ring to match the shift position indicator light.
3. Rearview monitor now standard on all models.
4. New dry carbon fiber rear spoiler on Black Edition.

title: 2013 Audi Q7
subTitle: A little bulky, but still an Audi
metaTitle: 2013 Audi Q7 - Buyer's Guide
metaDescription: 2013 Audi Q7 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Audi’s biggest car has some minor changes for the 2013 model year, but the basic package remains the same. The Q7 fits Audi’s model of good engineering, speed, and luscious interiors. Where it breaks the mold, of course, is in sheer size. With three spacious rows of seats, it can fit up to seven people; with all the seats down, it can fit pretty much anything you can think of. Audi axed a V-8 engine in 2012, and this year they have gone even further toward improving fuel efficiency by offering a new, lighter V-6 diesel engine that is twelve percent more fuel-efficient than previous diesel models, earning an impressive 28 mpg on the highway. The Q7 hasn’t received a major redesign in some years, and its age is showing, but with an updated grille and headlights on the 2013 model, some of that will be mitigated. The design of the interior will remain much the same, but available technology packages could turn the Q7 into your home away from home. The premium packages are rather expensive, but if you’ve got the money, you’re not likely to regret it. Options include a Bang & Olufsen sound system, a new split-screen rear video monitor, and Audi MMI technology.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competition:
1. BMW X5
2. Infiniti QX
3. Lexus LX

Cool Tech:
1. Available Bang & Olufsen sound system.
2. Available safety technology like lane assist and Pre-Sense to help during collisions.
3. New engine for diesel model, sedan-like fuel economy.

Looks:
1. Audi’s most spacious vehicle.
2. Available panoramic roof.
3. Available rear entertainment system.

New for 2013:
1. More efficient V-6 engine.
2. Available Audi MMI.

title: 2013 Nissan Juke
subTitle: 2013 Nissan Juke
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Juke Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Juke here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Nissan Juke stands out from the pack with its quirky looks and fun performance. It wins points as a driver’s car, but in the end may be impractical for some families. The Juke – which has been compared to a frog in the looks department – was designed to blend the benefits of a crossover with a sports car. The Juke’s standard turbocharged 1.6-liter inline four-cylinder engine provides 188 horses and punchy acceleration. The engine is linked to either a six-speed manual transmission or a continuously variable transmission that comes with the all-wheel-drive model. A three-mode drive selector – Normal for everyday driving, Sport for a more performance feel and Eco for maximum fuel efficient – gives the driver some interesting choices. Fuel economy is decent. The Juke with the CVT returns 27 mpg in city driving and 32 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. The six-speed manual transmission model returns 25 mpg in city driving and 31 mpg on the highway. Tight rear seats and a relatively small cargo hold may limit the Juke’s appeal. The printed fabrics and hard plastic trim in the cabin look a little cheap. The Juke is not for everyone, but it excels with a powerful engine, confidence-inspiring handling, and optional all-wheel drive – and there are eight models to choose from.
Fun-O-Meter: 7.5

Competitors:
1. Kia Soul
2. Mini Countryman
3. Scion xB
4. Scion xD

Cool Tech:
1. Three-mode drive selector is not unusual, but you’re seeing more of these on all kinds of cars, so it is a trend worth noting.

New for 2013:
1. A rearview monitor added to navigation package on SV models.
2. Revised Rockford Fosgate ecoPUNCH audio system added to SV navigation package and SL models.
3. Atomic Gold, Brilliant Silver, and Pearl White are new exterior colors.

title: 2013 Audi R8
subTitle: An irresistible performance-mobile
metaTitle: 2013 Audi R8 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Audi R8 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: All Audis are designed for speed, but most of them still look like a car a banker would drive to work. The R8 is the exception. Everything about the R8 screams speed, and it’s not just for show. The GT coupe makes it from in 0 to 60 mph in an almost alarming 3.6 seconds. For comparison, the speedy Audi A8 takes 5.7 seconds to make it from 0 to 60 mph. The R8’s performance is stellar, especially with the satisfying manual transmission. A choice between a V-8 or V-10 engine means there is plenty of power to get your heart racing. Fortunately, Audi has gone to significant lengths to make sure you won’t have to be scraped off the highway. More airbags than you can count and electronic Stability Control come standard, and the R8 has specially constructed crumple zones to protect passengers in the event of a collision. The interior is small, but two passengers can be quite comfortable in their leather sport seats. Drivers can choose between a coupe, an ultra-limited run Spyder, and a convertible. When you consider that the convertible will let you feel the wind in your hair and accelerate a touch faster than the coupe, it’s hard to resist.
Fun-O-Meter: 10

Competition:
1. Ferrari 458 Italia
2. Lamborghini Gallardo
3. Porsche 911

Cool Tech:
1. Extremely fast – top speeds just shy of 200 mph.
2. Standard ESC to help maintain control.
3. Available Audi MMI technology.

Look:
1. Standard leather sport seats.
2. Available soft-top convertible.
3. Unmistakable styling.

title: 2013 Nissan Leaf
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Leaf, an electric car, lets you drive past gas stations – but you will pay a price.
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Leaf ATS Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Cadillac ATS here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Nissan Leaf is in the vanguard of electric cars coming on the market in the U.S. It’s kind to the environment and it has become increasingly attractive, especially in an era of $4-a-gallon gasoline. But the EPA rates the Leaf’s driving range at 73 miles per charge – which makes the little EV impractical for anyone with a long commute. The federal government says there are only 4,466 public charging stations in the U.S., a statistic that may increase “range anxiety” for anyone who owns or is thinking about buying an electric car. Still, the Leaf has a lot going for it. The price is good for an electric car and the Leaf is eligible for federal and state incentives that can help to defray the cost. It drives like a “real” car with sprightly acceleration, zero tailpipe emissions, and a 90-mph top speed. The EPA rates the Leaf at the miles-per-gallon equivalent of 106 in the city and 92 on the highway – the second most fuel-efficient car in America after the Mitsubishi i. The downside is that Leaf home charging can take up to twenty hours without an optional quick charging station. The range can also vary depending on the weather and how much cargo you are carrying. The Leaf suffers from tight rear seats, small cargo space for a hatchback, and confusing cabin technology. But if you have short commutes, have no fear of running out of juice, and want to boost your green credentials, the Leaf may be the way to go.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Ford Focus Electric
2. Chevrolet Volt
3. Mitsubishi i
4. Toyota Prius

Cool Tech:
1. Owners can communicate with the Nissan Leaf remotely through their smartphones and computer through the Carwings system. The system lets them track the battery’s charge, save on energy costs by scheduling off-peak charging and pre-set the heat or A/C functions.

New for 2013:
1. Nissan says details on the 2013 Leaf will be available at a later date.

title: 2013 Audi TT
subTitle: Good things come in small, adorable packages
metaTitle: 2013 Audi TT Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Audi TT Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Before the R8 came along, the Audi TT was Audi’s sporty coupe in the United States. Sometimes overlooked as just a cute car, the TT is actually fast and well built, and it certainly won’t bore you. The 2012 model year saw the introduction of the very fast RS model (0 to 60 mph in 4.1 seconds), which put an end to complaints that the TT is too precious to perform. Available with either a 2.5-liter five-cylinder engine and manual transmission (the TTRS) or a 2.0-liter turbocharged engine, the TT has something for everyone. The TT’s interior is an interesting meld of racing-car-reminiscent shapes and materials with plush elements like sport seats and an optional navigation system. The exterior styling is just about perfect, exactly what you would expect from an Audi sports car. The TT gets more than 30 miles to the gallon on the highway, which might soften some of the sting of spending $50,000 to $60,000 on something so small. The 2013 model won’t see any massive changes, but new colors will join the TT’s palette, and all-leather, two-tone interiors will be available in the S and RS models. For the truly geeky, there are also new available nineteen-inch performance tires.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competition:
1. BMW Z4
2. Mercedes-Benz SLK
3. Porsche Boxster

Cool Tech:
1. Available Audi MMI navigation system with real-time traffic info.
2. Standard driver information system with lap timer.
3. Earns above 30 mpg on the highway.

Looks:
1. Impeccable exterior design.
2. Sport seats for driver and front passenger.
3. New color choices for interior and exterior.

New for 2013:
1. New exterior color options.
2. Optional leather interior for S and RS models.
3. Available performance tires.

title: 2013 Nissan Maxima
subTitle: 2013 Nissan Maxima
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Maxima Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Maxima here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Nissan Maxima absolutely gets the big stuff right. It has tons of power, a comfortable ride, bold exterior styling and an upscale interior. But despite being touted as a sport sedan by the Japanese automaker, its front-wheel-drive layout and continuously variable transmission make it fall short of its lofty goal. Dare we call it a family-friendly sedan without insulting Nissan designers? The five-passenger sedan serves as Nissan’s flagship, but it suffers from a smallish cabin. It is again offered in two models, 3.5 S and 3.5 SV, each powered by a standard 290-horsepower 3.5-liter V-6 engine. It returns decent fuel economy at 19 mpg in city driving and 26 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. One downside: the Maxima requires premium gasoline and that can raise your fuel budget compared to other models that get roughly the same ratings. The ride in the Maxima is well damped and comfortable with fairly limited body roll. The sloping roofline in the rear limits headroom for backseat passengers and the high beltline may make smaller passengers feel slightly claustrophobic. The biggest problem with the Maxima, though, may come from the Nissan stable. The less-expensive Nissan Altima sedan received a major makeover for the 2013 model year, which may steer some buyers away from Maxima once they step into a Nissan showroom.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Ford Taurus
2. Acura TL
3. Chrysler 300
4. Volvo S60

New for 2013:
1. New SV Value Package featuring nine-speaker Bose audio system, SiriusXM satellite radio, heated front seats, heated steering wheel, and heated outside mirrors.
2. Sport Package has been revised to add Monitor Package content, including seven-inch color monitor, USB connectivity, iPod net in center console, climate-controlled driver’s seat, and Dark Hyper Silver finished nineteen-inch aluminum-alloy wheels.
3. Pearl White is new exterior color.

title: 2013 Bentley Continental Flying Spur
subTitle: The four-door Flying Spur sedan is a more pronounced take on the Continental GT.
metaTitle: 2013 Bentley Continental Flying Spur Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Bentley Continental Flying Spur Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Flying Spur is a plus-size model. It weighs a whopping 5,456 pounds, but here is a super car that carries its weight well. While this hefty Bentley is big, it’s certainly no slowpoke. The Flying Spur reaches a top speed of 195 mph and the souped-up Spur Speed zooms up to 200 mph, and both do so with considerable grace and nuanced handling. The speed of the Spur in particular defies all logic – it’s a big car with excellent performance statistics. The Mulsanne may have edged it out on the flagship’s prestige category, but the Flying Spur is more than a dignified contender. Lambswool, leather and wood are Bentley calling cards found in the interior. The Flying Spur is twice the price as Mercedes-Benz S Class, but is also twice as refined in more subtle ways. A big engine, all-wheel drive and the extra brawn have their drawbacks at the pump — it gets 10 mpg city and 17 mpg highway. But if you’re Bentley bound, the gas bill probably isn’t your preeminent concern. Bentley has also improved its technology and now features top-of-the line entertainment and navigation. The Flying Spur is the super car that’s designed to blend in. It’s the sleep agent.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Rolls-Royce Ghost
2. Aston Martin Rapide
3. Maserati Quattroporte

Cool Tech
1. The Series 51 affords all the high-tech trappings in a singular package.
2. At one time the Flying Spur was lacking in space-aged accruements, but that is the case no more with the one-two navigation, phone, and touch-screen punch.

Looks
1. It’s hard to argue with classic. The styling of the Flying Spur has become the go-to look and so Bentley has remained true to the design first introduced eight years ago defined by a high and long roofline.

New for 2013
1. Not much here. The new Flying Spur will creep up on the market place in 2014, discreetly edging out its well-accomplished successor.

title: 2013 Nissan Murano CrossCabriolet
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Murano CrossCabriolet is one controversial crossover.
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Murano CrossCabriolet Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Murano CrossCabriolet here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Nissan Murano CrossCabriolet is the convertible version of the Nissan Murano crossver. It’s hard to find a more polarizing ride. Some are intrigued by its droptop fair-weather potential, others gripe that it looks bloated and ridiculous. The Murano CrossCabriolet is plagued by convertible issues like a body that shakes when it goes over bumps since it doesn’t have a solid roof to boost rigidity. It also offers minimal cargo space and has poor rear and side visibility. The unusual convertible gets a power cloth top roof, all-wheel drive and comes in just one model. It is equipped with a 265-horsepower 3.5-liter V-6 engine linked to a continuously variable transmission. In a rare twist on a convertible, the CrossCabriolet can tow up to 3,500 pounds. It can be dressed up with optional quilted leather-trimmed seating and comes with twenty-inch five-spoke titanium finish aluminum-alloy wheels. Standard safety features are plentiful and include dual pop-up roll bars for rear passengers. Nissan dropped the price of the CrossCabriolet for the 2012 model year and has not yet announced pricing on the 2013 model. Be prepared to pay more than you would for a conventional Nissan Murano. You should also be prepared to stand out in a crowd in this rare crossover, especially if you opt for Caribbean, a retro-looking aqua exterior color.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Jeep Wrangler
2. Land Rover Range Rover Evoque
3. Lexus IS C

New for 2013:
1. Nissan has not announced changes or pricing to 2013 CrossCabriolet.

title: 2013 Bentley Continental GT
subTitle: The world is yours when you’re driving the dashing Bentley GT coupe.
metaTitle: 2013 Bentley Continental GT Buyer's Guide - Jean Know Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Bentley Continental GT Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: You know you’re in the money when you’re driving the new Continental GTC, which is the convertible version of the two-door Bentley. In literal terms, the car is priced well over $200,000. Shopping for a Bentley is a not an off-the-rack experience. Here there are plenty of options in a neat laundry list including possible fabric and color combinations.  The Bentley GT is big and powerful, but surprisingly easy to drive, which sets it apart from other fussy, super-luxury cars with extra-sensitive gas pedals. The two-door Bentley was refreshed in 2011 followed by the 2012 convertible GTC. Bentley has broadened its engine portfolio, starting with its badass W-12 and now introducing the less thirsty and much thriftier V-8, which manages to pack a wallop of power. Next comes the GT Speed coming in September 2012 that, rumor has it, will be the fastest Bentley ever. Choose your poison, either way the GT is made for maxing and relaxing.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. BMW M6 Coupe
2. Aston Martin DBS
3. Mercedes-Benz CL63 AMG

Cool Tech:
1. You’ll find star-bright LED lamps.
2. At last Bentley has incorporation a much-improved touch screen navigation system.

Looks
1. Unlike past Bentley designs, the cabin is more futuristic than old library with "blood orange" illumination.
2. The natural leathers and hand-polished woods give the Bentley interiors a feeling of authenticity.

New for 2013
1. The V-8 gets a new grille and Bentley "B" set in a red background.
2. Bentley adds the more fuel-efficient V-8 engine to its lineup of super cars.
3. The Bentley is more "B" for boss with standard twenty-inch wheels.

title: 2013 Nissan Murano
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Murano provides fun and good fuel economy from a crossover champ.
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Murano Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Murano here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Nissan Murano used to stand alone in the crossover market as one of the few truly stylish offerings. That’s no longer the case, but the five-passenger Murano still is a solid competitor, especially for those looking for fun and good fuel economy. The one downside is that the Murano tends to be a bit expensive. What you get for the money is a pleasing exterior design that remains unchanged for the new model year. A wide chrome-and-mesh grille and triangular headlights prove to be a dramatic combination in the front, while a roof spoiler adds interest in the rear. Nissan beefed up the Murano for 2013 with advanced safety technologies added to the uplevel LE Platinum Edition and SL Navigation Package. The Murano again offers a standard 260-horsepower 3.5-liter V-6 linked to an Xtronic CVT. The combination offers smooth, powerful acceleration and returns 18 mpg in city driving and 24 mpg on the highway on the Murano front-wheel-drive model and 18 mpg in city driving and 23 mpg on the highway on the four-wheel-drive model. The ride is comfortable and relatively soft. A long list of options includes a dual panel power moonroof, eight-way power driver’s seat with power lumbar support, and SiriusXM satellite radio. The Murano is an excellent choice for small families who don’t want to sacrifice sensibility for style. You get both with this Japanese crossover.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Ford Edge
2. Honda CR-V
3. Mazda CX-5
4. Toyota Venza

Cool Tech:
1. Moving object detection helps the driver keep track of what’s going on outside the vehicle.

New for 2013:
1. Advanced safety shield technologies, including moving object detection, blind-sport warning and lane-departure warning systems added to LE platinum edition and SL navigation package.
2. A new SV value package with power liftgate, Bose Audio system with nine speakers and Nissan navigation system for SV models.
3. A new Titanium finish added to the eighteen-inch aluminum-alloy wheels on SV value package and SL models.
4. SV models get an auto-dimming rearview mirror and HomeLink.
5. Midnight Garnet and Gun Metallic are two new exterior colors.

title: 2013 Bentley Mulsanne
subTitle: If you’ve always wanted to be queen for the day, don’t just watch the throne. Test drive the Bentley Mulsanne and take your seat.
metaTitle: 2013 Bentley Mulsanne Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Bentley Mulsanne Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: "I’m here!" screams the Bentley Mulsanne. When you pull up in the Mulsanne, you most certainly have arrived. Hello darling, you’re driving a car that costs $300,000. The pristine and proper flagship from the British automaker is a statement unto itself. Look closely and you’ll notice aluminum front fenders. Hang on: you’ll experience the refined grumble of a sophisticated twin-turbo V-8 engine, but there is little noise that can make its way in this well constructed cabin.
