What you’re paying for in the Bentley is quality, detail and impeccable function.  Patience is part of the ethos of Bentley manufacturing. It takes a 170 hands-on hours to build a Bentley Mulsanne at the factory in Crewe, England. Bentley has added high-tech nuances from the get-go in the Mulsanne model, such as the eight-inch color screen and the sixty-gigabyte hard drive. Here’s where Mulsanne is besting itself with new packages and options for technological splendor. Now you can’t just park a Bentley Mulsanne anywhere, so please travel with an extra stack of $20 spots for the valets. Tipping anything less from the driver’s seat of the Bentley Mulsanne would be uncivilized.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Rolls-Royce Phantom
2. Rolls-Royce Ghost

Cool Tech:
1. An eight-inch color touch screen navigation system.
2. The sixty-gigabyte hard drive

Looks:
1. The stately exterior is couple with ingenious modifications to the interior including a leather-lined media player storage drawer and sumptuous deep pile carpets.

New for 2013:
1. The boss Executive Interior Concept offers the "theatre" and iPad choices.
2. The Theatre includes crystal champagne flutes and a refrigerator.
3. The package also boasts a 15.6-inch LED screen screen and two eight-inch screens encased in the headrests.
4. An Apple computer is installed in the trunk. It also has USB ports and an iPod Touch that has a Bentley app. The iPad package features two iPads and keyboards embedded in the wooden, fold-down picnic tray tables.

title: 2013 BMW 1-Series
subTitle: Although shorter in the bustle, it’s not short of bustle on the road.
metaTitle: 2013 BMW 1-Series Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 BMW 1-Series Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Despite being thoroughly good and fun in every way, the rather costly 1-series presents a difficult choice: why not spend somewhat more on a 3-series model and get more car? The primary virtue of the 1-series is its tidy compactness on a rear-wheel-drive chassis that aims true. You get the same menu of engines and transmissions as in the 3-series, but the 1’s overall lighter weight makes for exhilarating performance. The trade-off is that the only models available are the coupe and convertible. Life with a two-door compact can be a struggle, as when you’re hurrying to expel passengers at the airport. (By then, they’ll be overjoyed to get out of the cramped back seat.) But if rear passengers would be a rarity and driving thrills are your pursuit, the 1-series offers its own rewards. The 128i comes with a 3.0-liter 230-horsepower six-cylinder and the choice of a six-speed manual or automatic transmission. The turbocharged 135i slightly revises the six to blast off with 300 horsepower; that six-speed manual is standard, but an enthusiastic driver might prefer the seven-speed dual-clutch automatic’s legerdemain. The 1-series sacrifices none of the BMW essentials, only a few inches here and there, and has a pug-like menace all its own.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors
1. Audi A3
2. BMW 3-series
3. Volvo C30

Cool Tech:
1. Aggressively geared seven-speed dual-clutch automatic gearbox with paddle shifters.
2. Fully automatic operation of convertible top.
3. Front fascia includes air curtains to counter wheel well turbulence, cutting aerodynamic drag.

Looks
1. If a black, white, or red body holds no appeal, spend $550 for any colors in the optional palette of metallic hues.
2. Rich red terra cotta Boston leather upholstery is available.
3. For drivers in weather-beaten states, the 135i--which comes standard with eighteen-inch wheels and performance tires--can be had with seventeen-inch wheels and all-season tires.

title: 2013 Nissan Pathfinder
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Pathfinder undergoes an extreme makeover, shedding 500 pounds and a V-8 engine -- all in the name of improved fuel economy.
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Pathfinder Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Pathfinder here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Nissan Pathfinder has been transformed from a bloated SUV into a sleek crossover, undergoing one of the most dramatic transformations of any 2013 vehicle. The biggest knock against the outgoing model is that it was an old-fashioned SUV that was less refined than its rivals. The Pathfinder has shed its old V-8 engine, along with 500 pounds, and now returns 26 mpg on the highway. The 2013 Nissan Pathfinder FWD tips the scales at 4,149 pounds; in comparison, the lightest 2013 Ford Explorer weighs 4,448 pounds. The changes should translate to a more carlike ride. Although official pricing hasn’t been announced, Nissan says the Pathfinder is in line for a price cut and would start at less than $30,000. All 2013 Pathfinders now come equipped with a 260-horsepower 3.5-liter V-6 engine mated with a next-generation Xtronic continuously variable transmission. The 2013 Pathfinder will be offered in 4x4 and 4x2 configurations and in four models – S, SV, SL and Platinum. It has a standard towing capacity of 5,000 pounds, significantly less than the outgoing model. The seven-passenger Pathfinder has more cabin space than the previous model. Options include a heated steering wheel, thirteen-speaker Bose Premium Audio system, dual-zone climate control, and remote engine start. Parents will love the new Latch and Glide system in the Pathfinder. Families no longer have to remove the child seat every time someone needs access to the third row.
Fun-O-Meter: 5.5

Competitors:
1. Ford Explorer
2. Jeep Grand Cherokee
3. Chevrolet Tahoe
4. Honda Pilot

Cool Tech:
1. Latch and Glide system provides easier access to the third row and is expected to be copied by other automakers.

New for 2013:
1. All new.

title: 2013 BMW 3-Series
subTitle: Covering all bases in style, the 3-series offers a variant for everybody.
metaTitle: 2013 BMW 3-Series Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows cars
metaDescription: 2013 BMW 3-Series Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Just as the beagle endures near the top among most-popular dog breeds, the BMW 3-series is a perennial stalwart on automotive hit lists. This is the car that lets you say, “I’ve made it!” But it also says, “Outta my way!” When the sixth-generation 3-series appeared as a 2012 model, the winning formula was further reinterpreted and refined. That means it’s even more fun to drive, sleeker and more pleasing to look at, more luxurious, and better-equipped. As usual, what’s under the hood is excellent: the 300-horsepower 3.0-liter six-cylinder is included with the 335i. But the turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder in the 328i won’t disappoint anyone with 240 horsepower and greater frugality. There’s also the option of the six-speed manual transmission or a new eight-speed automatic. Equipped with the automatic transmission, the 328i gets 36 mpg highway and the 335i gets 33 mpg highway. Not bad! The forthcoming ActiveHybrid 3, which adds a turbocharger to the six-cylinder and combines its output with assist from an electric motor, promises an improvement in fuel efficiency without sacrificing sportiness. The 335is coupe and convertible make 320 horsepower with the six-cylinder, adding a performance edge. The all-new 3-series Sports Wagon will be available in the spring.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. Audi A4
2. Cadillac ATS
3. Lexus IS

Cool Tech:
1. The full-color head-up display projects information onto windshield, eliminating driver distraction.
2. Surveillance drones have nothing on the 3-series, which offers Surround View for a comprehensive look around the car and nearby area.
3. Hands-free trunk lid opening is achieved with just a wiggle of your foot under the rear bumper.

Looks
1. Clean lines and sharp creases give the car character--not effects, overused elsewhere, like front fender grilles.
2. Three available themes--Sport, Luxury, and Modern--determine the decor outside and inside, with striking and always tasteful results.
3. M Sport package adds aerodynamic body pieces and other unique trim.

title: 2013 Nissan Quest
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Quest is one of the most versatile and usable minivans on the market.
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Quest Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Quest here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Nissan Quest got a major redesign two years ago and enters the 2013 model year with just a few tweaks. The Japanese minivan holds up well against its competitors and merits a second look by anyone needing a family-friendly ride. The cabin in a minivan counts more than its exterior looks and the Quest does not disappoint in this area. It features one-touch, power sliding doors, quick release fold-flat second and third row seats and a useful rear storage well. The step-in height is lower than on other minivans, making it easier to get passengers in and out. The Quest gets a 260-horsepower 3.5-liter V-6 engine linked to an Xtronic continuously variable transmission. Fuel economy is decent at 19 mpg in city driving and 25 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. The Quest can be loaded up with lots of options designed to keep fussy kids happy, including an eleven-inch rear DVD video screen, Bose audio system and dual moonroofs that slide open. A total of six cupholders and six bottle holders are standard, along with four coat hangers and two 12-volt DC outlets. The dual-level front center console offers flexible storage, as does the removable second row console. An overhead front console is standard on SL and LE models. The Quest is often the forgotten minivan on shopping lists, but it shouldn’t be.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Chrysler Town & Country
2. Dodge Grand Caravan
3. Honda Odyssey
4. Toyota Sienna

Cool Tech:
1. Easy Fill Tire Alert lets owners know when the ideal inflation is reached with a beep of the horn, so no tire pressure gauge is needed.

New for 2013:
1. Addition of standard Around View Monitor on LE models.
2. DVD entertainment system now optional on SV and SL models.

title: 2013 BMW 5-Series
subTitle: The familiar executive sedan also bridges the gap to realm of utility.
metaTitle: 2013 BMW 5-Series Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 BMW 5-Series Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Whether you need cargo-carrying capacity or an executive express, the 5-series has you covered. The lineup’s oddity is the Gran Turismo. Its curved back bridges the gap between station wagon (one isn’t offered) and SUV. No holding it down, though, because it employs the same 400-horsepower twin-turbo V-8 and eight-speed automatic transmission from the 550i sedan. Or, you can settle for the 300-horsepower version of the turbo six-cylinder from the 535i sedan--not brutally fast but still pretty quick. Among the sedan entries, there’s also the 528i. Remarkably for this class and price range, the 528i goes about its business with a turbo four-cylinder. Then there’s the ActiveHybrid 5, in which the turbo six is assisted by an electric motor, their output going through an eight-speed transmission. As quick as it can be, the ActiveHybrid 5 can also creep along solely on battery power for 2.5 miles. Ask your neighbor if his Blutomobile can do that! Efficiency is spreading across the 5-series range, too, thanks to the automatic stop/start, which completely shuts off the engine while you sit at intersections, then restarts it when you release the brake. So every member of the 5-series is handsome, or at least interesting, luxurious, and full of advanced technology.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Mercedes-Benz E-Class
2. Cadillac CTS
3. Infiniti M-Class

Cool Tech:
1. Optional, dazzling 10.25-in display is shared with 7-series.
2. ActiveHybrid 5 can reach 37 mph inch all-electric mode.
3. ActiveHybrid 5 has electronics that work with navigation to “read” the route, storing electrical power for uphill stretches.

Looks
1. ActiveHybrid 5 also has galvanized grille slats and matte chrome exhaust tips.
2. You know the battery pack in the luggage area by its "ActiveHybrid Power Unit" inscription.
3. A black-panel display presents instruments and driver information.

title: 2013 BMW 6-Series
subTitle: Very fast, luxurious, stylish, and somewhat sporty in three appealing shapes.
metaTitle: 2013 BMW 6-Series Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 BMW 6-Series Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: A heavy emphasis on luxury while still providing satisfying driving dynamics distinguishes the 6-series. In addition to the two-door coupe and convertible, a third model, the Gran Coupe, joins the lineup for 2013. This swoopy four-door stretches 4.4 inches longer than the two-door version. Nothing says “exclusive” like white leather upholstery, and that’s how it can be trimmed inside while being fitted with twenty-inch wheels outside. That is, if you feel the danger of blending in with the crowd. Extra notes of distinction come from the available Bang & Olufsen audio system. Among the sixteen speakers, one pops out from its central location on the dashboard, provoking oohs and aahs to go with tra-la-las. Some ethereal lighting effects are also produced. The 640i Gran Coupe’s turbocharged 3.0-liter six-cylinder is familiar from the 640i coupe and convertible and makes 315 horsepower. The twin-turbo V-8 that’s shared among 650i models now makes 445 horsepower in the standard state of tune, although in the M6 it’s good for 560 horsepower. The Gran Coupe is only offered with an eight-speed automatic, while a six-speed manual is a choice with the 650i coupe and convertible. All-wheel drive is offered with the V-8 versions of the three models.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Audi A7
2. Jaguar XK
3. Mercedes-Benz CLS

Cool Tech:
1. Gran Coupe available with adaptive LED headlights that provide intense, evenly distributed beams of light.
2. All models come with Active Steering, which provides a rear-steer effect for around-town maneuverability and high-speed stability.
3. The Gran Coupe’s available Bang & Olufsen High-End Surround Sound System utilizes sixteen individually amplified speakers to create the acoustics of a reference listening room.

Looks
1. Gran Coupe is 4.4 inches longer than the two-door coupe.
2. Gran Coupe’s available M Sport package can include twenty-inch wheels.
3. Opal white leather trim with Amaro Brown accents was developed especially for the Gran Coupe.

New for 2013
1. The Gran Coupe is an all-new 6-series offering this year.
2. The Gran Coupe’s selectable Eco Pro driving mode uses instrument panel displays and electronic controls to coach the driver and improve efficiency.
3. Central display screen measures 10.2 inches in Gran Coupe.

title: 2013 Nissan Sentra
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Sentra compact sedan gets a significant redesign with a cut in horsepower, engine size and weight in the interests of better fuel economy.
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Sentra Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Sentra here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Nissan isn’t relying on hyperbole when it says that the redesign of the 2013 Sentra is the “most revolutionary” in the nameplate’s thirty-year history. The 2013 Nissan Sentra gets a more sophisticated look courtesy of a redesign that includes upscale touches such as LED-accented headlights and taillights. The high-performance – and thirsty -- Nissan Sentra SE-R and SE-R Spec V have been eliminated from the lineup. The 2013 Sentra gets a new 1.8-liter four-cylinder engine rated at 130 horsepower. The engine is linked to a continuously variable transmission or six-speed manual transmission. It is the only engine in the Sentra lineup. The EPA has yet to list official fuel-economy numbers for the redesigned Sentra, but Nissan says the 2013 Sentra FE+ models will deliver 40 mpg on the highway. The base 2013 Sentra returns 30 mpg in city driving and 39 mpg on the highway. Nissan says the changes to the Sentra result in a “13 percent improvement in EPA combined fuel economy.” The Sentra is 150 pounds lighter than the outgoing model. The compact sedan gets a soft-touch instrument panel, optional leather-trimmed seats and maple wood-tone trim. A new version of the Nissan navigation system is an option. With gasoline prices hovering near the $4-a-gallon mark all year, the revisions to the Sentra should be a welcome change to anyone reeling from pump prices.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Ford Focus
2. Honda Civic
3. Kia Forte
4. Toyota Corolla
5. Hyundai Elantra

Cool Tech:
1. Easy Fill Tire Alert honks horn when correct tire pressure is reached.

New for 2013:
1. New sheet metal.
2. New 1.8-liter four-cylinder engine.
3. Optional leather seats.
4. New version of Nissan navigation system.

title: 2013 BMW 7-Series
subTitle: Revisions for 2013 make this agile and luxurious sedan more appealing than ever.
metaTitle: 2013 BMW 7-Series Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 BMW 7-Series Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Never short on style or gadgetry, the 7-series is refreshed with some cool technology and a minor facelift that includes a new grille and larger air inlet for 2013. In the name of efficiency and fun, powertrains are revised for greater whoosh with less consumption. Now, for example, all engines work with an eight-speed automatic transmission. As before, the series offers a turbocharged six-cylinder in the 740i and long-wheelbase 740Li. This six is also included in the ActiveHybrid 7, whereas a V-8 had been offered. All 750 models, including those with all-wheel drive à la the 740Li, have turbo V-8s. Meanwhile, sitting on its throne, the range-topping 760Li could hardly be modest about its turbo V-12 producing 536 horsepower. On the tech side, LED headlights that produce a “natural daylight” type of high-contrast light are standard on the 760Li and optional on other models. The same 16-speaker Bang & Olufsen audio system that’s offered in the 6-series is available here, too. And the incorporation of 3-D into the navigation display makes the animation better and the displays more dynamic. The system also incorporates mobile-office functions with speech-to-text capability.  On top of everything else, the cruise control system all but steers the car in freeway traffic.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Mercedes-Benz S-Class
2. Audi A8
3. Jaguar XJ

Cool Tech:
1. To save fuel, auto start/stop on 740i/Li and 750i/Li kills the engine while you wait out red lights.
2. ActiveHybrid 7’s electric motor assists the six-cylinder upon strong demand for mid-range acceleration.
3. New navigation system includes 3-D and enhanced level of interactivity and includes voice-to-text funciton.

Looks:
1. Revised front apron features three-part air inlet with chrome bars.
2. New tail light lenses have different, more highly contrasting shades of red.
3. Redesigned front seats are sleeker.

New for 2013
1. Eight-speed automatic transmission is now included with all models.
2. The 9.2-inch screens for rear passengers appear to “float” on backs of front seats.
3. Bang & Olufsen Surround Sound System utilizes sixteen individually amplified speakers to create the acoustics of a reference listening room.

title: 2013 Nissan Titan
subTitle: 2013 Nissan Titan is big and powerful, but trails its American competition.
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Titan Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Titan here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Nissan Titan is big and powerful, appealing to weekend warriors who want the benefits of a full-size pickup truck for work and play. But with the new model year, the Japanese truck falls farther behind its American competition, especially in terms of engine offerings and fuel economy. The Titan gets just one engine, a standard 317-horsepower 5.6-liter V-8 linked to a standard five-speed automatic transmission, and no V-6 engine. This in an era when the 2013 Ford F-150 rolls out a restyled model with a range of engine choices, including a 302-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6 and a 365-horsepower 3.5-liter EcoBoost V-6. All F-150s get the more modern six-speed automatic transmission as well. The Titan lags well behind the competition in terms of fuel economy, with the two-wheel-drive version returning just 13 mpg in city driving and 18 mpg on the highway according to the EPA. There is no regular cab version of the Titan either. On the plus side, the PRO-4X Titan gets a mini-makeover for the new model year, with revised graphics, satin chrome grille, dark wheel finish, and a revised interior look. The Titan gets kudos for its macho styling, strong V-8, and good brakes, but it still is a dark horse when compared to its rivals from Detroit that seem better able to keep pace with the constant changes in the truck market.
Fun-O-Meter: 7.5

Competitors:
1. Ford F-150
2. Chevrolet Silverado
3. Ram 1500
4. Toyota Tundra

New for 2013:
1. PRO-4X model gets revised graphics, satin chrome grille, dark wheel finish, and revised interior.
2. New tailgate design with aerodynamic rear spoiler.
3. Step rails added as standard on SV and SL models.
4. Standard 120-volt outlet added to truck bed on SL models.
5. PRO-4X/SL moonroof and DVD packages added to options list.
6. New styled steel wheels added to S models and mudguards are standard on SL models.

title: 2013 BMW X3
subTitle: Downsizing the standard engine results in fuel savings without a loss of performance
metaTitle: 2013 BMW X3 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows cars
metaDescription: 2013 BMW X3 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The X3 can get expensive in a hurry, but it can get everywhere else in a hurry, too. That remains true even though a 2.0-liter four-cylinder replaced the six-cylinder that was initially offered in the X3 28i. This turbocharged four is very energetic and produces the same 240 horsepower as the old engine, but it burns fuel more frugally. That ought to put a smile on the face of anyone who takes satisfaction in doing more with less. Meanwhile, the X3 35i uses a 3.0-liter six-cylinder, and the output is 300 horsepower. An eight-speed automatic is the only transmission in the X3 range. Driving Dynamics Control allows you to select either of two sport modes, which regulate variability in steering effort, transmission shift points, and the vigilance of the stability control system, but the result is a jumpy, nervous vehicle that shifts gears frenetically. The normal mode is fine. A good thing about DDC, though, is the Eco Pro mode that monitors all onboard mechanical systems and electrical functions for efficiency. It even relays tactful suggestions about your lead-footed style of driving, if this is warranted. Quicker down the road, plusher inside, and better-riding than ever, the X3 has already made big steps forward. Now, add those further refinements.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Audi Q5
2. Cadillac SRX
3. Infiniti FX

Cool Tech:
1. Automatic stop/start, a standard feature adopted as a fuel-saving strategy, completely shuts off the engine while you sit at intersections, then restarts it when you release the brake.
2. Lane departure warning is a new option.
3. Direct injection helps the standard turbocharged four-cylinder engine to match the old six-cylinder’s output.

Looks
1. Nineteen-inch wheels are available on the X3 xDrive28i with the M Sport package.
2. The X3 xDrive28i receives eighteen-inch wheels and chrome tailpipes as standard equipment.
3. Panoramic moonroof is available with X3 xDrive35i.

New for 2013
1. Power tailgate is standard.
2. Eco Pro overall vehicle-efficiency mode is part of standard Dynamic Driving Control system.
3. Driver Assistance package (including lane-departure warning) is optional.

title: 2013 BMW X5
subTitle: Always a good sport, the X5 also has a service ethic.
metaTitle: 2013 BMW X5 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 BMW X5 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Every X5 model has plenty of get-up-and-go, but the original sporty SUV is also a highly involving driving experience. Engineers have devised several ways to counteract the natural tendency of such a tall and heavy vehicle to lean like a stagecoach in the turns. The suspension is fitted with so much adaptive capability that it might one day evolve into a steeplechase racer all by itself. Of the four engines available, none will allow the X5 to be embarrassed in a stoplight race with a bicycle messenger. Turbocharging extends from the gasoline-burning six-cylinder of the X5 xDrive35i and the V-8 of the X5 xDrive50i and X5 M, to the hard-working, efficient diesel six-cylinder of the X5 xDrive35d. Gas engines match up with the eight-speed automatic while the diesel is paired with a six-speed automatic. All-wheel drive is standard on all models. Towing capacity is as high as 6,000 pounds, and interior cargo space is as great as 75.2 cubic feet. The luxurious cabin offers seating for seven and all sorts of premium accoutrements. We’ve always loved the X5’s looks, and the current generation wears its body creases, contours, and ornamentation with a leading man’s ease. Adding the optional twenty-inch wheels provides that special touch.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Porsche Cayenne
2. Range Rover Sport
3. Infiniti FX

Cool Tech:
1. Available AdaptiveDrive reads the road, continually adjusting the suspension for superior cornering and ride characteristics.
2. Head-up display features variable image brightness and positioning.
3. Sideview cameras provide images of crossing traffic.

Looks
1. Available Nevada leather upholstery can be chosen in Oyster or Cinnamon Brown.
2. Twenty-inch wheels are available with M Sport package.
3. Restrained use of exterior chrome trim enhances the X5’s purposeful appearance.

title: 2013 Dodge Challenger
subTitle: Careful updates keep Dodge’s charismatic muscle car contemporary, relevant, and just plain hot.
promoTeaserSmall: Careful updates keep Dodge’s charismatic muscle car contemporary, relevant, and just plain hot.
promoTeaser: Careful updates keep Dodge’s charismatic muscle car contemporary, relevant, and just plain hot.
metaTitle: 2013 Dodge Challenger - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Dodge Challenger here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Coast through the streets of any American city in a Challenger, and prepare for many prolonged stares, thumbs up, and requests to rev the engine. Seriously, Dodge’s charismatic muscle car could be the best wing man (or wing woman) ever in terms of helping shy folks make friends. Despite receiving few updates over the years, the Challenger’s square-jawed styling is as fetching now as ever, with the new Rallye Redline package making even the base model look like a badass. The base Challenger is sort of badass, actually, with 305 horsepower available from its 3.5-liter V-6. Upgrade to the 375-horsepower R/T model to get more power and a pistol-grip manual shifter, or if you simply want to say yes when someone asks you, "That thing got a Hemi?" True horsepower addicts will love the 470-horsepower SRT8, which also happens to come with clever Track Apps that record acceleration, cornering, and braking performance to confirm that, yes, indeed, it really is fast. 

Regardless of what’s under the hood, the Challenger is built using the same big bones as the full-size Charger sedan, making it the only muscle car with five seatbelts. Also, despite its reverently retrospective styling and its intense interior ambiance, the Challenger offers countless luxury and convenience features, including an integrated Garmin-based navigation system, heated leather seats, and, on SRT8 models, an eighteen-speaker sound system with 900 watts that shouldn't have any problem drowning out the intoxicating exhaust note. But then, who’d want to do that?
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. Ford Mustang
2. Hyundai Genesis Coupe
3. Chevrolet Camaro

Cool Tech:
1. New launch control system for SRT8.
2. Track Apps for SRT8.
3. Integrated Garmin interface in Uconnect navigation package.

Looks:
1. V-6-only Rallye Redline package with red interior, black chrome twenty-inch wheels, red accents.
2. Available 900-watt, eighteen-speaker Harmon Kardon audio system.
3. Many custom accessories available, including seven wheel choices for non-SRT8 models.

New for 2013:
1. Available rear parking sensors.
|2. New colors: TorRed (SRT8 only), Billet Silver, Granite Crystal Pearl, Jazz Blue Pearl, Phantom Black.
3. Expanded adaptive shock system for SRT8.

title: 2013 Dodge Charger
subTitle: A whole lot of car, with a whole lot of attitude.
promoTeaserSmall: A whole lot of car, with a whole lot of attitude.
promoTeaser: A whole lot of car, with a whole lot of attitude.
metaTitle: 2013 Dodge Charger - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Dodge Charger here at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: With the Dukes of Hazzard’s General Lee in its bloodline, the 2013 Dodge Charger certainly has attitude. What other car, besides its corporate cousin the Chrysler 300, can be the perfect family car by day and star in rap videos by night? With rear-wheel drive or on-demand all-wheel drive, the Charger has also become the darling of law enforcement, if that means anything to you (just don’t expect it to get you out of any speeding tickets, trust us). Still, there are many reasons it can wear so many hats. First, it looks great, with a menacing stare and many Mopar accessories available to help you customize it to your liking (the Blacktop package is particularly hot, we think). It also has some chops, with a base V-6 making 292 horsepower, mated to an eight-speed automatic transmission that helps the big girl achieve 31 mpg on the highway. Spring for the 370-horsepower V-8 and it becomes downright fast, and for speed demons, a scary-looking 470-horsepower SRT-8 model is pure hooligan heaven. Finally, the Charger has a value story to tell, with base models starting under $26,000 (less than a V-6-equipped Toyota Camry), and dashboard trim rendered in real aluminum. Optional are sport seats, a simple Garmin-based navigation/infotainment system using a huge 8.4-inch screen, and even a Beats by Dr. Dre sound system. A full-size sedan with full-size character, the Dodge Charger is as American as a car gets.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Ford Taurus
2. VW Passat
3. Chrysler 300

Cool Tech items
1. Available Beats by Dr. Dre sound system.
2. Brakes with rain-brake support.
3. Fuel-saving cylinder de-activation.

Looks
1. V-6 Rallye appearance and Blacktop packages with twenty-inch wheels, sport seats, spoiler.
2. Steering wheel paddle-shifters for R/T Road & Track package.
3. Get-outa-my-way styling on SRT8 model.

New for 2013
1. Available on-demand all-wheel drive.
2. New colors: TorRed (SRT8 only), Billet Silver, Copperhead Pearl, Granite Crystal Pearl, Jazz Blue Pearl, Phantom Black.
3. Available black-painted roof.

title: 2013 BMW X6
subTitle: The utility vehicle for drivers who would prefer a coupe.
metaTitle: 2013 BMW X6 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 BMW X6 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: When it comes to the X6’s styling, the word “distinctive” is used. This unusual cross between a coupe and station wagon is also “interesting” and “different.” It squints at you from a wide and bold face. Creases in the hood emphasize the potential lying below with subtlety. At the very least, the X6 offers a turbocharged 3.0-liter six-cylinder making 300 horsepower in the X6 xDrive35i. The turbocharged V-8 is available in 400- and 550-horsepower versions with the X6 xDrive50i and the X6 M. Whereas the BMW X5, upon which the X6 is based, is unabashedly a sporty SUV, and the two vehicles share the same 6,000-pound towing capacity, the X6 never aspires to carry the entire crew: the car seats five, but the second row’s middle position gives new meaning to the phrase “in a pinch.”  With an all-wheel-drive system that can favor the outside wheels in a corner for surer grip, the X6 handles better than you might think. The sloping roofline and high-waisted body combine to make it hard for the driver to see all around, so the backup camera and available blind-spot detection are essential survival items.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Acura ZDX
2. Infiniti FX
3. Land Rover Range Rover Sport

Cool Tech:
1. Available adaptive LED headlights throw out brilliant beams of white light.
2. Heated front and rear seats.
3. Rear-seat entertainment system includes an 8.0-inch thin-film-transistor (TFT) screen.

Looks
1. More vivid, three-dimensional grille elements and frame distinguish this year’s model.
2. Standard Nevada leather upholstery offered in Vermilion Red; available Nappa leather in Ivory White.
3. LED tail lights wrap around from the X6’s rear to its sides, emphasizing the vehicle’s width.

New for 2013
1. Nineteen-inch alloy wheels for X6 xDrive50i.
2. M Sport package increases X6 xDrive35i engine output to 315 horsepower, xDrive50i output to 440 horsepower.
3. LED external lighting front and rear.

title: 2013 Dodge Dart
subTitle: Dodge resurrects an historic name for a history-making car.
metaTitle: 2013 Dodge Dart Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 2013 Dodge Dart here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: In case you aren’t an ardent car aficionado, Chrysler (and hence, Dodge) is now part of the Fiat family. Why bring this up? Because the 2013 Dodge Dart is the first new vehicle developed under Fiat’s stewardship for any of its new family of American brands, and not only does it fill a gaping hole in the Dodge lineup, it does so with real swagger. Despite being half Italian, the Dart exudes plenty of American style. Its proportions are European, but its unbroken strip of LED taillights spanning the trunk, à la the Charger, as well as the aggressive headlamp and grille treatment, are purely American. A choice of three four-cylinder engines (ranging from 160 to 184 horsepower) and three transmissions (including a conventional manual) furnish the engine bay, any combination of which should help keep one’s fuel bill manageable, though no Dart iteration achieves the magic 40 mpg fuel economy figure that has become the gold standard among compact cars. Inside the Dart, its somewhat 1990s-esque architecture detracts little from its generally pleasant ambience, and its calling cards include its availability in many flavors, each with smart ergonomics, and a huge back seat. Prices for its five available trim levels, which start under $17K and run into above $23K for the performance-oriented R/T model, are competitive compared to other compact cars. Then again, that’s darn cheap compared to most Italian automobiles.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Honda Civic
2. Ford Focus
3. Volkswagen Jetta

Cool Tech items:
1. Huge 8.4-inch display screen for UConnect audio and navigation system.
2. Active aero grille shutters for Limited model.
3. Seven-inch reconfigurable info screen on Limited model.

Looks:
1. Cool full-width LED taillamps.
2. Blackout grille treatment, eighteen-inch wheels, Nappa leather interior for R/T model.
3. Vast Mopar accessory catalog

New for 2013:
1. Everything.

title: 2013 BMW Z4
subTitle: Classic roadster proportions and enough under the hood to put some growl into your day.
metaTitle: 2013 BMW Z4 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 BMW Z4 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Although the Z4 sDrive28i received a turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder in place of BMW’s traditional six-cylinder, it remains an expensive car. It also remains a zippy one. You go from a standstill to 60 mph in 5.6 seconds. It uses the same six-speed manual or eight-speed automatic transmission offered in the turbocharged six-cylinder sDrive35i, although the more powerful car also has an available seven-speed dual-clutch automatic. Then there’s the top-of-the-line sDrive35is. Its 3.0-liter six-cylinder churns out 335 horsepower, and the seven-speed is the only transmission. The 35is shoots from 0 to 60 mph in 4.7 seconds. The Z4 is the only entry in BMW’s lineup in which all-wheel drive is not available because driven rear wheels remain the preferred configuration for sports cars. The Z4 has a long nose and bold styling, which is most evident in the way the character line flows off the front fender and bridges with the rear one. The car can be had in an outrageous Atacama yellow paint job that will shock the young in your neighborhood. Even greater shocks are reserved for when you start giving rides: this successor to the rather tepid Z3 is a heck of a performer.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. Mercedes-Benz SLK
2. Porsche Boxster
3. Nissan 370Z

Cool Tech:
1. sDrive35i engine weighs only 355 pounds, thanks to use of magnesium and aluminum.
2. Electrically assisted power steering is programmed for sporty feel.
3. Dual-clutch seven-speed automatic transmission adds thrills in sDrive35is.

Looks
1. Aerodynamic body kit is available on all three Z4 models.
2. Retractable hard top gives the Z4 an advantage; anthracite headliner doesn’t hurt, either.
3. Available interior trim of carbon interwoven with aluminum adds uniqueness.

title: 2013 Buick Enclave
subTitle: A crossover with all the quiet competence and blend-in aesthetic you expect from the Buick nameplate.
metaTitle: 2013 Buick Enclave Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Buick Enclave Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: If a car is a fashion statement, the Buick Enclave is the polo shirt and pressed chinos of the automotive world—competent and a bit sedate. It’s also massively popular, with sales topping 57,000 in 2011, proving that the crossover is truly the new station wagon for the discerning family. Moderately restyled for 2013, the Enclave is offered in both front-wheel-drive and all-wheel-drive versions, and in Convenience, Leather, and Premium trim levels. All have a V-6 engine and six-speed automatic transmission that yield 24 mpg on the highway for the front-wheel-drive model. The four-wheel-drive model does slightly less, with 22 mpg on the highway. The three rows really do accommodate three rows of full-size passengers, but in consequence, there’s less luggage space in the back than might be desired, at a maximum of 23.3 cubic feet if you leave all rows of seats in place. Safety features include a front center side air bag, which Buick notes is an industry first, and a standard rear-vision camera. A power liftgate and remote start are both standard. Luxury add-ons abound, including a premium audio system, color-touch radio with DVD and navigation plus a seven-inch touchscreen, an eight-way passenger’s seat adjuster, and choccochino and cocoa leather color combinations for the interior.  The chrome accents are real, the stitching on the door trim and interior is real, and so is Buick’s commitment to the upscale family buyer.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Ford Flex
2. Honda Pilot
3. Acura MDX

Cool Tech:
1. Front center side air bag—now every square inch of the front seat is protected, surely.

Looks:
1. Choccochino and cocoa leather color combinations.
2. Dual stainless steel exhaust.

New for 2013:
1. Mild makeover includes new hood, fenders, and grille plus lighting upgrades.
2. Interior gets a front center side air bag, Buick calling it industry first.
3. Revised suspension technology.

title: Interstates Are for Wimps!
promoTeaserSmall: JKC's associate editor makes the most of the fleeting days of youth.
promoTeaser: JKC's associate editor makes the most of the fleeting days of youth.
metaTitle: Interstates Are for Wimps! - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Interstates Are for Wimps! A trip on the Pacific Coast Highway in a 2003 Nissan Murano by JKC associate editor Annie White.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Staying put doesn’t come naturally to me. I lived in one place for most of my young life, and all I ever thought about was getting out. The summer after my freshman year of college, I never stayed in the same place for more than six days in a row. By the spring of my senior year, I had lived in three cities in the space of nine months and was growing restless again.

So, with one month to go to graduation I stuck a map of the United States on the wall above my bed and, in the cliché of old, started sticking thumbtacks in it. One in each “must-see” national park. One in Nashville, one in New Orleans, one in San Francisco, one in Portland, one in DC. Then I took a pencil and mapped the route. No interstates, interstates are for wimps and long haul truck drivers. No hotels, hotels are for rich people and parents with small children.

If you’ve never mapped a circuit around the United States that uses only state highways and stops only at campgrounds, I can tell you that it is a long, long road. If you’ve never tried to plan a several-month-long vacation with the budget of a college student who has recently spilled her savings across Western Europe, I can tell you that it is almost impossible. So I rethought. I left the pins in Portland, San Francisco, and Yosemite. I drew a big, thick line down the Pacific Coast Highway, that road of legend. As far west as you can go without falling into the ocean. It’s not the fastest way from Portland to San Francisco, but I felt sure that it was the only way worth going.
Oregon Coast, fog and infinity

Two months after graduation, as the second week of August dawned and a truly fantastic breakfast from the Pelican Brewery in Pacific City, Oregon, settled in my stomach, my cousin Ellen and I took to the road. We’d flown in to Oregon the week before and spent several days playing sand volleyball and climbing the dunes with a sampling of family members, one of whom enabled our flight south by lending us a 2003 Nissan Murano, referred to as Orange Car by those who love it.
 
In Oregon, Highway 101 alternates between flat, straight sections of road that run through tourist towns and curving, climbing portions that hug the cliffs and weave through forests. Sometimes I would whip around a corner (always driving a little too fast because why not?) and suddenly realize we were on the edge of land, nothing between us and the sea.

When the sky is clear, this is exhilarating. To your left, mossy cliffs. To your right, blue. Blue forever, as far as you can see, and you feel like if you let go of the wheel you would fly off and explode in a blaze of glory. And you’re almost tempted to, except you know it’s just a feeling and what would really happen is you would tumble off the road and smash into the rocks below, nothing glorious about it.

When the sky is not clear, when the fog is pressing in and you can’t see more than fifty feet in front of you, it’s a litmus test. The space behind the fog could be infinity or oblivion. Heaven and hell and god and death and everything could be back there. Or it could just be fog and nothing else.
Among the Giants

Our planning for this Great Adventure had essentially amounted to saying “It’ll be fine, right?” and marching inexorably forward as if we actually knew what we were doing. We had friends and relations who we thought would be able to put us up, we had a car and (we were fairly certain) enough money to keep it fueled up. We had a tent and a camp stove; we had a really unnecessary amount of beer and bacon. I often travel this way, and it has always worked for me. I find it less stressful – if you don’t have plans you can’t worry about messing them up. Of course this all falls apart if the universe fails to provide you with something essential, like a place to sleep or transportation. But then, what is the ground for? What are your feet for?

That first day we drove to Prairie Creek Redwoods State Park in Northern California. A few months before, I had camped in the same park for two nights and hiked fourteen miles deep into the woods almost without seeing another soul. This time we didn’t have time for a hike, but after snagging the last campsite in the park and setting up camp in the pitch dark we sat below the starriest sky I’ve ever seen with a cold beer and a brat each. When I lived in Boston, I was excited when a move across town and further from the city lights brought exactly five stars into view. In the Redwoods, I was pretty sure that that whole thing in the bible about god numbering the stars was straight bullshit.
Sunshine

The next morning, I took the first shift again and was soon forced into a reluctant detour from Highway 101. We had to cross the mountains so that we would be directly north of Yosemite. We found ourselves weaving through the mountains for four hours, nervously checking the fuel gauge against the distance to the next town. Around lunchtime, I pulled to the side of the road in a sparkling valley with a low river running through it. This is the great thing about the West Coast – you go there expecting mountains and forests and river valleys that glisten in the late afternoon sunlight and the place delivers.

We waded in the river and reveled in the fresh mountain air. At that moment, it was hard to imagine ever wanting to be anywhere else. In fact, the only thing that got me driving again was knowing I would be soon be speeding back down the mountain on a wickedly twisty road with no one else around.

Four days later, after 25 (or so) miles hiked, three swims in mountain streams, one hitchhiking trip (the first of my life; we taught an Ecuadorian couple how to pronounce “squirrel”) two gas fill-ups at more than $5 per gallon, and at least twelve moments in which I was astonished that places like that even exist, we headed north again by way of San Francisco.

Driving back across the mountains further south, we travelled a section of road that rested hundreds of feet above a huge reservoir, its level visibly depleted by drought. It seemed completely plausible that we would miss one of the hairpin turns, and as we swept into the valley, with Orange Car’s steering responding almost as quickly as I wanted it to, and I kept thinking: “I am going to die on this road.” Call me crazy, but part of me loves moments like that, moments when I’m almost out of my depth. When I’m not really sure if I can hack it. But I always do, because there’s no other choice.
The best kind of driving is the kind that pushes the limits. Find the boundary between sane and not, then ride it as hard as you can.
Back to Portland

The drive back to Portland took at least twice as long as we wanted it to. This was mainly due to the fact that Highway 1 driving north from San Francisco was designed either by a madman or someone who thought that cars would never go faster than thirty miles an hour, or maybe both. It would be the drive of a lifetime if you had a car that was designed for its ability to negotiate demanding roads and not for its ability to hold three car seats. In Orange Car, we had to balance our desire to survive the trip with my desire to drive really fast (Ellen is much more sensible). We ended up driving carefully, but also slowly. After a week of driving in perfect, beautiful countryside we almost wished there were just a straight shot home. I say almost, because the drive was still nothing short of wonderful.

By the time we made it to our campsite, we were tired and not particularly interested in cooking (I don’t want to tell you how many Cheetos we ate on that trip, but it was enough that neither of us was hungry for dinner). And even though the two and a half hours I spent that night trying to build a fire ended in ashes and broken dreams, I was still content.

I had spent a week hanging out with family and friends, and almost nothing had gone wrong. The weather was beautiful; we didn’t get hurt or sick. The people we met lent us maps and wisdom and mattresses and fed us delicious food. We swam in mountain streams. We didn’t get eaten by bears.
By my estimation, our luck only deserted us once, in that last night at that last campsite with the fire that refused to become a fire.

People love travel for different reasons. Some people don’t love it at all. I’ve always felt the call to wander, and I’m rarely disappointed by what happens when I step out my front door. The world is an endlessly fascinating place, and driving across part of it is as good a way to see it as I can come up with. The fact that I got to wring a car out on the mountain roads is just a bonus.
