title: 2013 Dodge Durango
subTitle: Square-jawed looks, rugged structure and castle-sized cabin make the Durango something out of a fairy tale.
metaTitle: 2013 Dodge Durango Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Dodge Durango here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Once upon a time, there was a plus-size, three-row SUV called the Dodge Durango, which lived in harmony with virtually no enemies. Then came a slew of three-row crossovers from its competitors, and the Durango had no choice but to evolve. Evolve it did, and after becoming a crossover itself two years ago, people liked it. The Durango has found many happy homes ever since. It is more powerful and more capable, thanks to a strong 290- to 295-horsepower V-6 (depending on model) and an even stronger available 360-horsepower Hemi V-8. Like its predecessor, it comes with rear-wheel drive or all-wheel drive, but unlike before, today’s Durango is smooth and stable on the road, not bumpy and tippy. It has more usable space in its refined interior, seating six or seven people, with thirty storage spaces and, with the seats folded, room for a six-foot couch. And of course, it is dashingly good-looking. Since it's available in base SXT, nicely equipped Crew, sporty Hemi-powered R/T, and formal Citadel trim levels, selecting a Durango may be somewhat hard. That's especially true because of the newly available Rallye Appearance group that helps the SXT models look like an R/T, and the Premium Leather package that brings red-stitched, super-soft leather to the R/T. If there are bones to pick, it’s that fuel economy is less than amazing, and prices can creep pretty high with all the option boxes checked. That said, 2013 prices have dropped for some models will help this automotive fairy tale keep its happy ending.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Ford Explorer
2. Honda Pilot
3. Chevrolet Traverse

Cool Tech Items:
1. Available blind spot monitor and rear cross-path detection.
2. Available forty-gigabyte hard drive with navigation, Bluetooth streaming audio available.
3. Available powered, USB-connected second-row console (with captains chair option).

Looks:
1. Lower ride height, twenty-inch wheels, unique interior on R/T.
2. Second-row captains’ chairs, walk-through center console.
3. Available Nappa leather seating surfaces on R/T.

New for 2013:
1. Lower prices for many models.
2. Rallye Appearance package for SXT model with exclusive Redline red color.
3. Standard leather upholstery and heated front and second-row seats for Crew model.

title: 2013 Dodge Grand Caravan
subTitle: The Grand Caravan may be more fun to drive than it is to look at, but America’s original minivan remains very easy to live with.
metaTitle: 2013 Dodge Grand Caravan Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Dodge Grand Caravan here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: You may not know it by looking at it, but the Dodge Grand Caravan may be the most enjoyable-to-drive minivan you can buy. Yeah, it’s not often that the words “minivan” and “fun to drive” are used in the same sentence, but in this case—and that of the GC’s Chrysler-branded twin, the Town & Country—it’s the surprising reality. Credit thorough re-engineering for 2011 that banished the sloppy handling and gooey steering usually associated with such domesticated vehicles. Less surprising is the way it accommodates families with up to seven members and all of their attendant accoutrements. In addition to the abundant space, kid stuff—and the second- or third-row seats themselves—may be stowed (with one-handed operation) in deep reservoirs in the floor of most models. The GC comes in five flavors: AVP, SE, SXT, Crew, and R/T, the first two priced very aggressively (the AVP starts under $21,000), and the latter three featuring the highest amount of popular equipment. Our favorite is the R/T model (which Dodge has lightheartedly referred to as the “man van,” with its monochromatic paint, a tighter suspension, seventeen-inch satin carbon wheels, black leather upholstery, red stitching, and a whomping sound system. All Grand Caravans are powered by the same meaty 283-horsepower V-6 mated to a six-speed automatic transmission. Compared with the Honda Odyssey and Toyota Sienna, the Grand Caravan may be a tad smaller, but it is tons more fun.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Nissan Quest
2. Honda Odyssey
3. Toyota Sienna

Cool Tech Items:
1. Safety Sphere package with park assist, backup camera, blind spot assist, rear cross path detection.
2. Stow-in-place roof rails with scissor-style roof bows.
3. Third-row powered rear vent windows.

Looks:
1. R/T model with sport-themed interior, exterior treatment, subwoofer.
2. Black/sandstorm interior color combo available for non-R/T models.

New for 2013:
1. Prices lowered on some models.
2. Rear-seat entertainment with Blu-ray player, dual nine-inch screens.
3. Billet Silver, Maximum Steel and Blue Streak exterior colors added.

title: 2013 Dodge Journey
subTitle: Aggressively priced and entirely pleasant, the Journey is still finding its way to customers
metaTitle: 2013 Dodge Journey Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Dodge Journey here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Dodge has been on a journey lately, and one particularly sad episode of its journey is, well, the Journey. A three-row, up-to-seven-passenger crossover made from the rib of the chunky, plasticky Avenger sedan back in 2007, the Journey didn’t stand a chance from the beginning. A thorough revamp, however, in 2011 brought with it tidier handling and a vastly improved interior, including one particularly cool white-on-black upholstery treatment offset by orange stitching. What the Journey did not get was dramatically different styling, which would have helped it lure people away from more established crossovers like the Ford Edge, Honda Crosstour, and Hyundai Santa Fe, to name a few. And so the Journey continues to struggle in spite of Dodge having groomed it into a reasonably nice tall wagon/small minivan. It is available in five trim levels, with top-tier Crew and R/T models (the latter being the “sporty” one) offering a legitimately luxurious driving experience. The steering is communicative, and the thrust from the available 283-horsepower V-6 is outstanding, even with optional all-wheel drive. And we love how its second-row under-floor bins hold chilled soda cans or muddy shoes. Best of all, it is one of the most aggressively priced crossovers around, with most 2013 trim levels priced lower than in 2012, starting at under $20,000 for the AVP and the range-topping R/T model starting at just under $30K. Is that enough to get consumers’ attention this year? Probably not, but it is a respectable value for those who notice.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Ford Edge
2. Honda Crosstour
3. Toyota Venza

Cool Tech Items:
1. “Ring of fire” LED taillamps standard on all models.
2. Keyless enter-and-go access and ignition.
3. Intelligent electronically controlled all-wheel-drive system.

Looks:
1. Aggressive front and rear lower fascia on SXT, Crew and R/T.
2. Standard seventeen-inch wheels (AVP, SE).
3. Leather upholstery, nineteen-inch wheels standard on Crew and R/T (both unique for each).

New for 2013:
1. Lower prices.
2. Winter Chill Pearl, Fathom Blue exterior colors.

title: 2013 Buick Encore
subTitle: Offering versatility and luxury in a very small package, the Encore is part of Buick’s push to reach younger consumers.
metaTitle: 2013 Buick Encore Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Buick Encore Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: To borrow a phrase from a previous General Motors brand, this is not your mother’s Buick. The brand-new Encore is a Continental take on the crossover utility vehicle. It is built on the same platform as GM’s Europe-market Opel Corsa, meaning it is small. Really small: 168.5 inches long, shorter than a Honda Civic and very close to the same size as the compact Audi A3 hatchback. In fact, Buick is going after the same kinds of buyers who look at Audi’s A3. The Encore is a front-wheel-drive vehicle with a turbocharged four-cylinder engine, and an all-wheel-drive model is available. The interior is similar to those in other current Buicks such as the Verano sedan, with a center instrument panel featuring Buick’s voice-activated IntelliLink system and its seven-inch color display screen, as well as blue ambient lighting. The Encore is loaded with safety equipment and electronics, including ten airbags, traction control, remote start, Bose premium audio, and a heated, leather-covered steering wheel. Options include a backup camera and front and rear parking sensors. Active noise cancellation and heavy use of sound-dampening technology such as an acoustically treated headliner should get this small vehicle closer to the serene feeling one expects from a Buick. Time will tell if American buyers will flock to this five-passenger crossover; it goes on sale in the U.S. in early 2013.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Audi A3
2. Lexus CT200h
3. BMW X1

Cool Tech:
1. Active noise cancellation.
2. Forward collision alert and lane departure warning. Both features use a single forward-looking camera sensor (cheaper option price than radar or a combination of radar and camera).

Looks
1. Flip-down storage compartment for phone to left of steering wheel.
2. Blue accents in headlamps.

title: 2013 Buick LaCrosse
subTitle: Buick sedan has old-school comfort and refinement, drawn with clean, modern lines
metaTitle: 2013 Buick LaCrosse Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Buick LaCrosse Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: What could be more American than a full-size sedan? Interestingly, though, the Buick LaCrosse is aimed just as much at buyers in China as those in the United States. Logical, since Buicks are actually bigger sellers there. A benefit of that market strategy is that rear-seat room is generous in the LaCrosse, because chauffeurs often drive this type of car in China. If you plan to do your own driving, you have two choices of engine. There’s a mild hybrid four-cylinder—meaning the engine is supplemented by an electric motor and a lithium-ion battery that improve fuel economy but don’t power the car by themselves. With that engine choice, fuel economy is an impressive 36 mpg on the highway. Who would expect that number from a sedan this size? The other engine is a V-6, required if you want the full-time all-wheel-drive version of the LaCrosse. Rear park assist, blind spot alert, and thorax air bags for the rear seat are all options. New for 2013, IntelliLink is standard on all models; it connects your smartphone to an eight-inch touchscreen display and lets you stream music through your phone from Pandora and other Internet-based services. All this, and Buick-style quiet, too.
Fun-O-Meter: 4

Competitors:
1. Acura TL
2. Lincoln MKS
3. Lexus ES350
4. Volvo S60

Cool Tech:
1. Standard eAssist cuts fuel delivery during decleration, uses electric motor and lithium-ion battery for regenerative braking; both are fuel-economy improvers.

Looks
1. Buick "signature" blue ring in xenon headlamps.
2. Smoked chrome accents.

New for 2013
1. Standard IntelliLink on all models.

title: 2013 Hyundai Santa Fe
subTitle: The Hyundai Santa Fe gets a major redesign for 2013 and now comes in two flavors: a five-passenger model and a seven-passenger model that replaces the Hyundai Veracruz.
metaTitle: 2013 Hyundai Santa Fe Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Hyundai Santa Fe here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Hyundai Santa Fe has been rejuvenated to appeal to families big and small who want a crossover vehicle. The Santa Fe now comes in a five-passenger Sport version and a larger, three-row, seven-passenger model that replaces the Hyundai Veracruz. The bigger Santa Fe won’t be available until January. The Santa Fe went on a major diet and shed 266 pounds versus the outgoing model. The result is a big improvement in fuel economy, with the base Sport model returning 33 mpg on the highway. Two engine choices are available in the Sport model: a 190 horsepower 2.4-liter four-cylinder GDI engine and a 264-horsepower turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder GDI engine. The larger Santa Fe gets the 290-horsepower 3.3-liter GDI V-6 engine. All engines are linked to a six-speed transmission. The Korean crossover is available with front-wheel drive or all-wheel drive. The 2013 Santa Fe has a more sculpted look and standard chrome exterior touches. Families will appreciate the flexible seating arrangements and the attention to safety features, including seven standard air bags. There are lots more extras, too, including such options as a panoramic sunroof, push-button start, heated steering wheel, and a second-row seat that slides. The Santa Fe used to be priced more attractively than the competition, but that may no longer be the case. The 2013 Santa Fe gets a significant price increase versus the 2012 model, courtesy of all the upgrades.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Ford Explorer
2. Chevrolet Equinox
3. Nissan Pathfinder
4. Toyota Highlander

Cool Tech:
1. New Driver Selectable Steering Mode, which lets the driver pick three operating modes – comfort, normal, and sport -- depending on driving preferences and road conditions. (Unusual in this segment)
2. Hyundai’s first application of Active Cornering Control all-wheel drive, a system that can anticipate traction needs and deliver additional stability through braking.

New for 2013:
1. All-new crossover architecture.
2. Two-model strategy with five-passenger and seven-passenger models.
3. New exterior look.

title: 2013 Hyundai Sonata
subTitle: The 2013 Hyundai Sonata is the Korean automaker’s highly regarded bread-and-butter family sedan that is gearing up to do major battle in the midsize sedan segment.
metaTitle: 2013 Hyundai Sonata Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Hyundai Sonata here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The sleek 2013 Hyundai Sonata is a carryover model with a few improvements, including the addition of heated seats as standard equipment to all models and packages except the base GLS model. The Sonata, which had a major redesign two years ago, is widely regarded as a world-class effort and a worthy competitor to the Toyota Camry and Honda Accord. But the segment is more competitive than ever this year, with the redesigned 2013 Ford Fusion and 2013 Nissan Altima vying for attention from consumers. Hyundai eliminated the base Sonata GLS with a six-speed manual transmission from the 2013 Sonata lineup. The base sedan now is equipped with a 200-horsepower 2.4-liter GDI four-cylinder engine linked to a six-speed automatic transmission. The base Sonata also gets a $1,100 price increase over the outgoing base model. The uplevel Sonata Limited gets a 274-horsepower 2.0-liter turbocharged GDI four-cylinder engine and six-speed automatic transmission. The 2013 Sonata with the 2.4-liter inline four-cylinder engine gets a respectable 35 mpg highway rating, according to the EPA. The Sonata can be transformed from a family hauler to a near-luxury car with the addition of such options as a $2,900 Limited Premium package that includes a panoramic sunroof, navigation system, rear back-up camera, and Infinity premium speakers and stereo components. The 2013 Sonata comes standard with three months of XM Satellite Radio. Every 2013 Sonata has electronic stability control as standard equipment.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Ford Fusion
2. Toyota Camry
3. Honda Accord
4. Nissan Altima

Cool Tech:
1. One of the few midsize sedans to offer digital HD Radio Technology from the factory.
2. Hyundai Blue Link telematics system is the Korean answer to OnStar and Sync. Has “Geo Fence” feature that sends you an email if car goes over a set speed limit (designed for parents to keep track of kids).

New for 2013:
1. Heated seats added as standard equipment to all models and packages except base GLS model.
2. Sunroof choices expanded for Sonata Limited.

title: 2013 Buick Regal
subTitle: This is a more interesting car than you might think. Whether you’re looking for fuel economy or driving excitement, there’s a Regal worth looking at.
metaTitle: 2013 Buick Regal Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Buick Regal Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Consider for a moment the Buick Regal. You may see this mid-size sedan as serviceable but uninteresting. But what about the Turbo, which gives you 270 horsepower worth of driving interest? Then there’s the eAssist mild hybrid model, which gives you 36 mpg on the highway thanks to its lithium-ion battery and electric motor that work together to power regenerative braking and save fuel. Did we mention that Buick’s IntelliLink is standard on all models? That system hooks up your smartphone and other mobile devices, lets you customize programming, and allows streaming audio from your phone via Pandora or other Internet services. Last but not least, consider that the Regal is based on the European Opel Insignia, and you might find yourself looking at this Buick in a different light.  Traction control, foglamps, leather-trimmed seating, heated front seats, ice blue ambient lighting, and a seven-inch touchscreen are all standard on every model. The GS turbo model has special tuning, including a modified front suspension, but no all-wheel-drive option. GS models have an interactive drive control system with standard, sport, tour, and enthusiast-oriented GS settings; it’s optional on the turbo. A set of twenty-inch polished alloy wheels is optional on GS models, too. All of that helps explain why the Regal is the core of Buick's product line.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Acura TSX
2. Audi A4
3. Lincoln MKZ
4. Volkswagen CC

Cool Tech:
1. eAssist with the standard 2.4-liter four.

New for 2013:
1. Buick IntelliLink now standard on all models.
2. Heated steering wheel on turbos except GS.

title: 2013 Hyundai Tucson
subTitle: The carryover 2013 Hyundai Tucson gets a price increase for the new model year, with the base GL model passing the psychologically important $20,000 mark for the first time.
metaTitle: 2013 Hyundai Tucson Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Hyundai Tucson here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Hyundai’s small sport-ute used to be among the value leaders in the marketplace, but that’s no longer the case. The carryover 2013 Hyundai Tucson, which gets a few tweaks for the new model year, crossed what may be a critically important barrier for some shoppers when it passed the $20,000 mark for the first time. The base 2013 Hyundai Tucson GL starts at $20,070, including an $825 destination charge. Hyundai has been steadily moving upmarket with all of its vehicles lately – but the good news is that Tucson is still significantly cheaper than most of its Japanese competition, including the Honda CR-V. The 2013 Tucson gets some modest upgrades, including heated front seats on the GLS FWD model, a proximity key entry with push-button start on the Limited trim, foglights, and automatic headlight control on the GLS. The Tucson is also a stellar performer at the fuel pump. The Tucson GLS with a 176-horsepower 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine and six-speed automatic transmission returns 22 mpg in city driving and 32 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. The Tucson also gets high marks for its agile handling and responsive steering. The Tucson can be ordered with an all-wheel-drive system. The 2013 Tucson with AWD features hill start assist control and downhill brake control, two features typically found on luxury SUVs. Families will appreciate the amenities, too, including nineteen different storages places and drink holders in the cabin.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Honda CR-V
2. Nissan Rogue
3. Toyota RAV4
4. Ford Escape

Cool Tech:
1. The 2013 Tucson with AWD features hill start assist control and downhill brake control, two features typically found on luxury SUVs.
2. The GL manual transmission model has a shift indicator to inform drivers when to upshift and downshift, a feature that can return fuel savings of seven to nine percent.

New for 2013:
1. Heated front seats on GLS FWD.
2. Proximity key entry with push-button start on Limited trim.
3. Fog lights and automatic headlight control on GLS model.

title: Where to Find Driving Moccasins
promoTeaserSmall: Just because you shouldn’t drive in your stilettos doesn’t mean you have to go barefoot.
promoTeaser: Just because you shouldn’t drive in your stilettos doesn’t mean you have to go barefoot.
metaTitle: Where to Find Driving Moccasins - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Where to Find Driving Moccasins: Check out some of these fashionable, yet practical, driving moccasins to keep your feet comfy on longer trips.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Just because you shouldn't drive in your stilettos doesn't mean you have to go barefoot. Instead of getting your clean feet all over your dirty gas pedal (or vice versa) you can slip into some fashionable, comfortable driving moccasins for your journey. Finding drivers at a department store should be easy, with dozens of styles offered by brands across the price spectrum.

For the budget conscious, Halogen offers a few brightly colored styles for under $100, while Frye and Michael Kors have high quality options for around $200. If money is no object, Tod's has the best selection for women, with leather and suede moccasins ranging in price from $400 for a colorful-but-basic pair to $1325 for a limited edition, hand-embroidered pair - for the "demanding and unconventional" woman.

Men will find their best selection at Gucci, with shoes available in exotic leathers like ostrich and python. The most expensive pair is an extremely suave set of crocodile loafers with bamboo accents for a cool $1850. If you're looking for something more obviously car-related, Puma sells a line of supercar-inspired driving shoes for around $100. Crocodile leather they're not, but still fashionable in their own right.

images.caption: Tod's Specials
Classic Gucci Look
Prada Driver

title: 2013 Infiniti EX
subTitle: The 2013 Infiniti EX is getting a little long in the tooth, but still manages to convey a sense of high style.
promoTeaserSmall: The 2013 Infiniti EX is getting a little long in the tooth, but still manages to convey a sense of high style.
promoTeaser: The 2013 Infiniti EX is getting a little long in the tooth, but still manages to convey a sense of high style.
metaTitle: 2013 Infiniti EX - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Infiniti EX here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Two major changes are on tap for the 2013 Infiniti EX – a 325-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6 engine that replaces the previous 3.5-liter V-6 and some new nomenclature. Gone is the EX35 model and in its place is the EX37. Infiniti says the rear-wheel-drive model returns 17 mpg in city driving and 25 mpg on the highway. The EX37 is getting a little long in the tooth and is due for a major revision. Despite that, the midsize luxury crossover that seats five still manages to convey a sense of high style. The crossover, which also can be ordered in all-wheel-drive configuration, earns kudos for its acceleration and handling. Front-seat passengers are coddled, but back-seat passengers may feel like second-class citizens. It’s just plain cramped back there, plus there is limited cargo room in the rear. Standard features are plentiful and include leather-trimmed seats, a smart key with push-button start, and eight-spoke eighteen-inch aluminum-alloy wheels. But it’s a mystery why upscale Infiniti charges extra for an optional driver’s seat headrest coat hanger and the better audio systems. There’s lots of useful technology as well, but be prepared to pay extra for it. Those options include a blind spot warning system, lane departure prevention system, intelligent cruise control, and intelligent brake assist with forward collision warning. The 2013 EX starts at $37,300, including an $950 destination charge, making it $2,645 cheaper than a base 2013 BMW X3. But keep in mind that the optional premium package on the EX37 adds another $3,050 to the bottom line, while the tech package costs $2,750.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. BMW X3
2. Acura RDX
3. Mercedes-Benz GLK-Class

Cool Tech:
1. Optional Around View monitor uses four small cameras located front, side, and rear to give the driver a “top-down view” of the outside of the vehicle and help reduce blind spots when parking.

New for 2013:
1. EX37 model replaces previous EX35 model.
2. 325-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6 replaces previous 3.5-liter V-6.

title: 2013 Buick Verano
subTitle: Buick’s smallest sedan, cousin to Chevrolet’s Cruze, now available with turbo.
metaTitle: 2013 Buick Verano Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Buick Verano Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Buick’s Verano made its debut in 2012 as the smallest sedan in the Buick lineup. It is built on the same platform as Chevrolet’s Cruze, but targeted at a more discerning demographic. It’s aimed at buyers who might consider an Audi or a Volvo, offering them a cheaper domestic alternative. The Verano is slightly larger and has more powerful engines than the Cruze—its engines are sourced from Buick’s larger Regal—and it also has premium touches such as wood trim, a center-stack dashboard with standard IntelliLink, and a rearview camera as standard. A heated steering wheel, leather interior, and a power sunroof are all available. New for 2013, there’s a turbocharged four-cylinder engine. This model offers 250 horsepower while providing 31 mpg on the highway, only a 1-mpg penalty over the standard engine, for the Verano with the six-speed manual transmission that’s a no-cost option. Mileage figures for the turbo Verano with automatic transmission aren’t out yet. This sedan nominally seats five but would be more comfortable for four. Another less than comfortable feature is the overly busy front end. It features a set of portholes that, although a traditional Buick design cue, are out of place on this small car.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Audi A3
2. Acura ILX
3. Volvo C30

Cool Tech:
1. Forward collision alert/lane departure warning with single camera sensor (cheaper option price than radar or radar/camera combination).

Looks:
1. White diamond tricoat exterior paint color.

New for 2013:
1. Turbo engine.
2. Standard IntelliLink on all models.
3. Standard rear-view camera on all models.

title: 2013 Infiniti FX
subTitle: The 2013 Infiniti FX line puts the “sport” in sport-utility vehicle, but that may make it an impractical choice for some families.
promoTeaserSmall: The 2013 Infiniti FX line puts the “sport” in sport-utility vehicle, but that may make it an impractical choice for some families.
promoTeaser: The 2013 Infiniti FX line puts the “sport” in sport-utility vehicle, but that may make it an impractical choice for some families.
metaTitle: 2013 Infiniti FX Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Infiniti FX here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Infiniti FX37 and FX50 are among the sportiest of the sport-utility vehicles and among the best when it comes to turning heads and tackling twisty roads. But some families may find they sacrifice comfort for the sake of looks and performance capabilities. The cabin is somewhat cramped, there is limited cargo room in the rear and kids may gripe that they can’t see too well from the rear seat. The ride quality in the FX line may be a bit too harsh for commuters and the school carpool as well. Still, performance is top notch with the base FX37 model getting a new standard 325-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6 engine. Rear-wheel drive is standard on the base model and all-wheel drive is optional. The top-of-the-line FX50 with all-wheel drive gets a beefy 390-horsepower 5.0-liter V-8 engine. Both engines are linked to a standard seven-speed automatic transmission. Both models have double-wishbone front and multilink rear suspensions and large four-wheel disc brakes. The cabin is richly appointed and there are lots of extras like optional sport seats that hold the passengers in place during hard cornering and make the driver feel like she’s Danica Patrick. Solid magnesium paddle shifters are optional and enhance the FX’s performance-oriented personality. The FX line may not be the best choice for hauling your kids and pets, but it does have one unusual accessory that would be perfect for sleepovers: a “hatch tent” that converts the cargo area into a sleeping area.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. BMW X6
2. Porsche Cayenne
3. Land Rover Range Rover Sport

Cool Tech:
1. Moving object detection added to Around View system for 2013.

New for 2013:
1. FX37 model replaces FX35 and includes standard 325-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6.
2. Iridium Blue exterior color offered for all models except Limited Edition.
3. Limited Edition available only with Moonlight White with Graphite interior color combination.
4. Java interior color available with Liquid Platinum and Graphite Shadow exterior colors.

title: 2013 Infiniti G
subTitle: Infiniti simplifies and strips down the 2013 Infiniti G lineup, discontinuing the gateway-to-the-brand G25 sedan.
promoTeaserSmall: Infiniti simplifies and strips down the 2013 Infiniti G lineup, discontinuing the gateway-to-the-brand G25 sedan.
promoTeaser: Infiniti simplifies and strips down the 2013 Infiniti G lineup, discontinuing the gateway-to-the-brand G25 sedan.
metaTitle: 2013 Infiniti G Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Infiniti G here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Infiniti G has been praised as one of the most driver-focused vehicles in the entry-luxury segment, with an entertaining rear-wheel-drive chassis and responsive engines. The lineup includes sedan, coupe, and convertible models. In a somewhat puzzling move, Infiniti has simplified and stripped down the 2013 Infiniti G lineup, discontinuing the base G25 sedan, G37 Sport Appearance Edition, and G37 Limited Edition, leaving the upscale Nissan brand without a true competitor to the Lexus IS 250. The Infiniti G37 Coupe base model is no longer available. There are now only three models in the G sedan lineup: the G37 Sedan Journey, G37 Sedan Sport 6MT, and G37x Sedan AWD.  Prices range from $37,795, including an $895 destination charge, for the base Sedan Journey to $42,395 for the Sedan Sport 6MT. All Gs now get a standard 328-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6 engine mated to either a seven-speed automatic transmission or a six-speed manual transmission. The G convertible is our least favorite of the body styles because the retractable hard top can squeak and creak on all but the smoothest roads. The G gets high marks for good handling, user-friendly controls, and attractive cabin materials. The G37 still ranks as one of the most fun-to-drive cars in its class, but the cramped rear seat in the coupe and convertible models is best left to small kids.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Audi A4
2. BMW 3 Series
3. Lexus IS
4. Mercedes-Benz C-Class

New for 2013:
1. Simplified sedan lineup.
2. G37 coupe base model no longer available.
3. Revised stone interior color with graphite components on coupe.
4. Standard Silk Obi aluminum interior trim replaces Shodo aluminum trim.

title: 2013 Infiniti IPL
subTitle: Infiniti shakes up the 2013 Infiniti Performance Line with the addition of a new IPL G Convertible.
metaTitle: 2013 Infiniti IPL Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Infiniti IPL here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Infiniti’s Performance Line jacks up the more prosaic G lineup with the 2013 IPL G Coupe and the addition of a new, four-passenger IPL G Convertible. The main gripe against the IPLs is that they are overpriced. The IPL G Convertible starts at $61,495, including an $895 destination charge, making it $8,600 more expensive than the base 2013 Infiniti G37 convertible. The IPL G Convertible is equipped with a 343-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6, seven-speed automatic transmission, IPL-tuned exhaust and suspension, nineteen-inch special wheels, and a three-piece retractable hardtop. Surprisingly, the exterior color choices on the new convertible are limited to just two: Malbec Black or Moonlight White. The droptop can be dolled up with extras like the $360 Midnight Black grille and $340 illuminated kick plates. A $545 rear wind deflector is a practical option, especially if you’re worried about your hair. Standard features include leather-trimmed seating and antilock brakes. The IPL G Coupe comes in two models, one with a seven-speed automatic transmission and another with a six-speed manual transmission. The IPL G Coupe gets a different look than its G sibling thanks to a different front and rear bumper design, sculpted side sills, a rear spoiler, and fancy nineteen-inch wheels. The pricing on the 2013 IPL G Convertible is designed to fall in between some of its toughest German competition. It is less expensive than the BMW M3 convertible, but more expensive than the Audi TTS roadster.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. BMW M3 Convertible
2. Audi TTS Roadster

New for 2013:
1. New IPL G Convertible.
2. Monaco Red interior now offered on G37 Coupe IPL 6MT models.
